item.title: New Ph3 Study Comparing Takeda's Leuprorelin 6M with Leuprorelin 3M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Hormone dynamics, pharmacokinetics, safety, and efficacy of the 11.25 mg and 22.5 mg formulations will be assessed in prostate cancer patients previously treated with hormonal therapy (HT). Primary endpoint will measure the rate of suppression of serum testosterone to castrate level.
Recruitment: 164
Start date: March 2012
Location: Japan

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bellicum Raised $10M to Fund POC Programs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Bellicum, a privately held biotherapeutics company headquartered in Houston (Texas), plans to initiate a Ph2 DeCIDe vaccine study in 2012 for the treatment of patients with metastatic castrate resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC), and a Phase 1/2 study of a T cell infusion product for patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
BPX-101 is an autologous DeCIDe™ vaccine.
Description
BPX-101 is comprised of matured, prostate cancer antigen-expressing dendritic cells derived from monocytes collected from the patient in a leukapheresis procedure, and modified so that they can be activated by a proprietary drug, AP1903.
Administration
BPX-101 is administered intradermally, followed 24 hours later by a two hour infusion of AP1903. This one day delay gives the cells time to migrate to the patient’s lymph nodes, where they are activated by AP1903 – in the right place and at the right time to drive a maximal anti-cancer immune response.

item.title: Teva and Oncogenex Update Custirsen Ph3 Program in CRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Teva and Oncogenex have amended their collaboration to enhance development plans for custirsen in advanced prostate cancer. As a result, the clinical trial program will now include the initiation of a new Ph3 study to evaluate if custirsen has the potential to improve OS for prostate cancer patients when combined with Jevtana® (cabazitaxel). Updates of the SATURN and SYNERGY trials are provided below.
  • Design: to show a survival benefit with 85% power based on hazard ratio of 0.75, or approximate 25% increase in survival time when custirsen is combined with cabazitaxel for second line chemotherapy
  • Start date: H2 2012
  • Recruitment: approx. 630
  • Location: in lieu of the cancer SATURN study
Analysts @ Blommburton expect this trial to take at least 4 years as survival times for the control group are expected to be 12-18 months, and it could take at least 2 years to recruit patients. Thus, they would not expect data until end of 2016 or early 2017.
(NCT01188187)
Primary endpoint: OS
Timelines: The trial continues to accrue patients and is expected to complete enrollment later this year. Results are expected Q4 2013.
Recruitment: Teva/Oncogenex are increasing the enrollment from 800 to 1000 patients to optimize the potential to be submitted to regulatory agencies independent of additional Phase 3 studies. The increase in enrollment is not expected to alter timelines for completion of the study.
(NCT01083615)
Primary endpoint: pain palliation
Status: will be stopped
The SATURN trial experiences difficulties recruiting a sufficient number of patients in a timely manner due to the eligibility criteria requiring stable baseline pain and analgesic use in men who have end stage cancer pain.
As announced at the ASCO GU conference, a Ph2 study of OGX-427 in combination with abiraterone is planned for later this year in men with CRPC (pre or post chemo ?)

item.title: MDV3100 to Enter POC Study as Neoadjuvant Prior to Prostatectomy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Ph2 study is planned to start this month, in approx. 50 men with localized prostate cancer. The primary outcome measure will assess the pathological complete response rate.
(MDV3100-07)
Timelines
Completion dates: June 2013 / Aug. 2013
Protocol
One arm: MDV3100 160mg, orally, once daily
One arm: MDV3100 160mg, orally, once daily in combination with leuprolide 22.5mg, IM Q 3 months + Dustasteride, 0.5mg, PO, QD

item.title: Key Messages from Acino's FY2011 Results
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: FY2011 revenues grew by 6% to EUR 134.9 million (2010: EUR 127.5 million) supported by Mepha acquisition. The Operating Segment Parenteral (transdermal systems and ER parenterals) achieved sales in 2011 of EUR 33.5 million (vs EUR 36.7 million in 2010). Acino reported that the the short-fall was primarily related to lost German and UK sales of goserelin. Of note the timelines for the launch of goserelin and leuprorelin are 2013/EU and 2013 respectively. Acino expects 2012 revenue of EUR 240-260 million.
By early 2013, the company plans to move to own R&D building in Aesch. The purchased Mepha site in Aesch (Canton Basel- Landschaft, Switzerland) comprises:
  • an FDA-compliant manufacturing facility,
  • office space
  • an R&D unit focused on the development of oral formulations
Mepha is transferring a number of its existing generic R&D development projects to Acino’s pipeline. Going forward, Mepha will continue to source products from its former site in Aesch, adding B2B-sales for Acino.
"

item.title: Janssen Has Unblinded ZYTIGA® (abiraterone) Ph3 Pre-Chemo Study (COU-AA-302)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Based on unanimous recommendation of IDM Committee, the company has unblinded the international, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled study for the treatment of asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients with mCRPC who have not received chemotherapy. The company plans to submit for regulatory approval in the US and around the world beginning H2 2012.
Differences in radiographic progression-free survival, overall survival, and secondary endpoints were observed and constitute evidence of clinical benefit as well as continued evidence of favorable safety in patients receiving abiraterone acetate plus prednisone as compared to those receiving placebo plus prednisone.
The results will be presented at an upcoming medical meeting (probably ASCO 2012), and will also be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.
Recruitment: approx. 1,088 patients
Protocol: patients were randomized to receive ZYTIGA 1,000 milligrams (mg) administered once daily plus prednisone 5 mg administered twice daily or placebo plus prednisone 5 mg administered twice daily.
The co-primary endpoints of the study are radiographic progression-free survival and overall survival.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Allergan's Management Meeting with Analysts
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ahead of March 28 R&D Meeting, analysts met with CEO Pyott and SVP Treasury Hindman. Management believes the top 3 most promising pipeline candidates are Latisse (for hair loss), targeted Botox (for pain), and DARPin (for wet AMD). Although Collins Stewart believe there are not likely to be any new pipeline products revealed on R&D Day, Morgan Stanley expect possible unveiling of new candidates, coming from the Ph2 pipeline.
Levadex for Migraine
  • The FDA action date for MAPP's Levadex for acute migraine is on Monday, Mar. 26.
Botox in OAB
  • Botox Phase III data in OAB in 1H:12
Management believes a launch of Botox Therapeutic in the iOAB indication would have a marginal advantage because medical directors at many managed care organizations may already be familiar with Botox Therapeutic in urology given the ongoing launch of the product in neurogenic overactive bladder. Additionally, the procedure is not completely new for most urologists, so a trained base of physicians will already exist if Botox is approved in iOAB.
Targeted Botox
  • Targeted botox Phase II data in post-herpetic neuralgia in 1H:12
Botox Cosmetic and Juvederm/XC
According to Management, Merz' Belotero has still not launched despite U.S. approval ~3 months ago, and Belotero was not developed with lidocaine, a major disadvantage to fillers such as Juvederm XC which are used with lidocaine to lessen the pain of injections.
Additionally, Allergan now sells a 1mL syringe of Juvederm for the same price as the 0.8mL syringe, so essentially physicians are getting more for their money. The company believes that it can maintain and grow its share of the dermal filler market in the U.S. as well as globally with the addition of Juvederm Voluma (filed at the end of 2011 in the U.S., already on the market in Europe/Canada). Management noted that Voluma addresses a different area of the face than Juvederm XC (the cheek area versus deep lines around the mouth) and physicians have stated that they have not seen another facial filler product like it. For example, in Canada, one of AGN‟s largest overall markets in terms of sales, management noted that Juvederm Voluma added 40% to the complete Canadian filler market over the 18 months that it has been available.
Pyott emphasized that the company expects 2012 R&D spending to be higher than expected.

item.title: API Prescriptions Reach 60% Within Three Months of Royal Decree 9/11 Enforcement in Spain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Although prescription by API reached an average of 60% in the first three months of Royal Decree 9/11 enforcement (October–December 2011), inconsistent applications in different autonomous communities will continue to lead to uneven results in the short-to-medium term unless the new government reassesses the Decree's rules on prescriptions and drafts specific guidelines for the communities to follow. A series of very inconsistent results has been recorded during the first three months since the Royal Decree 9/11 on mandatory prescriptions by active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) came into force in Spain in October 2011.
According to Diario Medico, although the national average for API prescriptions is 60%, some regions such as Andalucia, Navarra, Canarias and Madrid are hitting 80% prescription by API, and others such as Galicia, Catalonia and Asturias are below average, with 30%. According to the source, Andalucia is top of the list with 88,8% of prescriptions by API, followed by Navarra (86.9%), Canarias (85%), Madrid (80%), Cantabria (78.3%) and Castilla y Leon (75.6%). Bottom of the list are Asturias with 24.3% of prescriptions by API, Catalonia (26.3%), Galicia (28.8%), La Rioja (32.5%), and Baleares (44.5%). Mid-table positions were achieved by Aragon (53.3%), Murcia (54.4%), Castilla-La Mancha (61.1%), Valencia (63%), Pais Vasco (65%), and Extremadura (60%).
According to the Spanish GP association SEMG's secretary Moises Robledo, cited by the source, these variations are due to the degree of flexibility that autonomous communities have granted to regional doctors and pharmacist for the prescription of generic drugs as opposed to branded products of equivalent price or cheaper. According to the source, although savings made by the antonomous communities and the central government are equivalent if a prescription is a generic or a branded version of the same price or cheaper, the size of the pharmaceutical market changes. In fact, since the enforcement of Royal Decree 9/11 and the consequent need for brands to lower the prices of their products to keep competitive on the market, the size and revenues of the Spanish pharmaceutical market was reduced from EUR4 billion (USD5.2 billion) to EUR2.5 billion in 2011.
As a consequence of cheaper branded drugs competition, generic sales also dropped by an average of 7%, with great differences among different autonomous communities. According to the source, all major generic molecules reduced their sales apart from escitalopram, as the company selling its branded version Lexapro, Forest laboratories, decided not to lower the price of their product, therefore generics sales of escitalopram are still 100% among all communities. In some cases, branded prescription is still necessary as in the case of Zyprexa (olanzapine), where substitution with an equivalent generic product is still considered controversial.

The inconsistent results on the percentage of mandatory prescriptions by API produced by different autonomous communities in Spain are a result of a flexibility in the decree application. Although some communities such as Navarra were forced to stick to prescribing the cheapest generic, others such as Asturias allowed pharmacists and doctors more freedom to prescribe either a generic or a branded version of a certain drug as long as it represented the cheapest on the market.
This forced most brands active in Spain, such as Merck and Bayer, to lower the price of their over-the-counter (OTC) drugs in order to be competitive on the market, leading to a EUR1.5 billion decrease in pharmaceutical revenues since 2010. Although varying between different autonomous communities, generic sales also dropped by an average of 7% (source: Diario Medico) due to brand price competition. Of all the government's austerity measures, Royal Decree 9/11 has managed to prove the most effective in reducing the country's pharmaceutical debt while also creating an unfavourable climate for pharmacies and pharmaceutical associations which have been hit by a drop in sales and lower revenues. As a consequence of the decree, Spain managed to save EUR1.4 billion in 2011 on prescriptions.
Nevertheless, according to the Spanish Pharmaceutical Association (FEFE)'s forecast, this decree will lead to substantial losses for small-to-medium sized pharmacies, which are forecast to reduce their sales by EUR68,180 per pharmacy per year, with marginal losses of up to EUR15,000 per pharmacy per year. By the end of 2012, pharmacies are expected to lose an average EUR100,000 per pharmacy per year as a consequence of the price cuts and imposed generic prescription laid out by the country's three Royal Decrees. The hurdle for the new Spanish government will be in stablishing the sustainability of such austerity measures in the current economic climate and accommodating this to the needs of balancing governmental expenditure and those of the pharmaceutical associations.
Although prescription by API reached an average of 60% in the first three months of Royal Decree 9/11 (October– December 2011), inconsistent applications in different autonomous communities will continue to lead to uneven results in the short-to-medium term unless the new government reassesses the Decree's norms on prescriptions and drafts specific guidelines for the communities to follow. This mandatory generics pattern will only become consistent if the government sets equal guidelines to be followed by all communities.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Blocks Merz from Selling Xeomin
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A J. Guilford, a US district judge in Santa Ana (CA), issued an injunction preventing Merz from selling Xeomin after Allergan claimed its trade secrets were stolen. Findings and conclusions are awaited on March 9th. The commercial introduction of Xeomin for cosmetic use is scheduled for March 12 @ the annual meeting of the American Academy of Dermatology in San Diego.
Allergan alleges that Merz targeted Allergan sales reps who brought along confidential materials, including sales figures and customer lists.
The case is Allergan v. Merz, 11-00446, U.S. District Court, Central District of California (Santa Ana).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Intelligence From The Recent EAU Meeting - Bone Targeted Agents
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The two symposia on these agents were sponsored by Amgen covering denosumab and Bayer its Radium-223 therapy. Both speaker panels were multi-disciplinary, discussing phase III data with case studies presented during the Amgen symposia. From the data shown, it seems Radium-223 is a cleaner drug with a demonstrated OS benefit which can even be used in patients unable to tolerate docetaxel.
Highlights from the Bayer Symposia Bayer’s combi-presentation discussed the present and future directions of RCC and CRPC. The CRPC talk commenced with Nicolas Mottet discussing the challenges in treating CRPC and then fast-forwarding to 2010, new agents became available: sipuleucel-T, cabazitaxel, abiraterone, cabozantinib and denosumab. Overall, he mentioned that these new products are expensive and sequencing to optimize patient survival still needs to be defined, specifically with cabozantinib and denosumab. Mottet focused on bone protection efficacy but stressed that there is no real effect on overall survival. He then moved onto the future where TAK-700 was described as ‘something like abiraterone but perhaps without a low dose steroid’ while MDV3100 was referred to as ‘really a new class of anti-androgen receptor blocker …. it has a totally different MOA’
He also spoke of the need for oncologists to be involved in treatment decisions, calling for a multidisciplinary approach
Next, Sten Nilsson discussed the advantages and limitations of surgery and radiotherapy in the management of bone metastatic CRPC and moved on to radionuclides, outlining Alpha vs. Beta treatment – stating that Alpha has shown both pain relief and OS benefit
He followed by introducing Radium-223, showing the phase I and II study designs and results - well tolerated and bone marrow toxicity was low
Dr. Chris Parker spoke last with a presentation titled ‘Rising Stars: Innovations in treatment bone metastases in CRPC’ where he discussed the interim data from the ALSYMPCA phase III study. The data showed that Radium-223 is well tolerated and significantly prolonged OS, time to first SRE and time to spinal cord compression.
Bayer is aiming for Radium-223 to be a new standard of care for the treatment of CRPC patients with bone metastases. During the Q&A session, delegates spoke of the logistic and radioprotective hurdles to which the panel retorted are non-issues; ‘there are no issues with this, it can be delivered to all centres…a simple pair of gloves is sufficient and the half life is 11 days’. The product will be ordered on demand and will not be stored on site. It is also understood that the expanded access trial in the USA will open in the next few weeks while the EU expanded access trial will open mid year.
An unusual aspect of this design is the inclusion of patients who are unfit for docetaxel.
The study is well balanced in terms of their age, ethnicity, performance status, extent of disease and baseline pain.
Treatment was more complete with radium-223 over placebo (more patients on placebo dropped out).
There were more overall adverse events seen with placebo group although there was more mild diarrhea and vomiting with the active drug
Highlights from the Amgen Symposia
The Amgen symposia was based around 3 case studies looking at denosumab and zoledronic acid usage, highlighting the advantages of denosumab (longer time without an SRE, less pain, no dose adjustments needed as there is no renal toxicity) and finally ending with their Phase III data on bone metastasis prevention in CRPC trial (superiority over zoledronic acid).
The below slide outlined the positioning of these agents, in that bone targeted therapy does not compete with the other treatments but is intended to be used in combination.
Despite this data, the ODAC recently recommended against approval of denosumab for this indication (see Oncology8094: re: Amgen Not Guaranteed Success At Tomorrow's ODAC Meeting)
The CI department gratefully acknowledges coverage of these symposia by Beth Elliott

item.title: Regeneron to Report Interim Study Findings in 1st-line Hormone-Resistant mPCa
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During its presentation @ Cowen Group H/C conference, management confirmed that results from the VENICE cancer Ph3 trial will be reported "early in this year in the first half of 2012".
Title: Aflibercept in Combination With Docetaxel in Metastatic Androgen Independent Prostate Cancer
Primary Endpoint: OS
Recruitment: approx. 1200
Aflibercept is a fusion protein designed by Regeneron scientists to bind two forms of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (called VEGF-A and VEGF-B).

item.title: Intelligence From The Recent EAU Meeting - Janssen & Astellas Symposia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:The Janssen Cilag and Astellas symposia were well balanced in terms of providing coverage of the new and pipeline agents within mCRPC. J&J's new trial with abiraterone in the hormone naive metastatic segment also featured. Key discussions revolved around the need for sequencing data and how to best utilise the new and upcoming treatment arsenal.
He went on to explain Jansens extended Phase III programme and highlighted the imminent results announcement of COU-AA-302 (ASCO 2012) investigating the use of abiraterone as a first line therapy in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic patients. With PEACE-1 exploring the efficacy of abiraterone in newly diagnosed (hormone-naïve) prostate cancer patients.
At the end of his talk Dr Fizazi mention Takaeda’s Orteronel (TAK-700) dual Phase III programme also targeting the enzyme 17 α-hydroxylase/C17, 20-lyase (CYP17).
The results of MDV3100 Phase III trial AFFIRM were described, demonstrating impressive results. Emphasis during this section of the talk was placed on the balanced patient baseline characteristics, efficacy was observed across all subgroups and MDV3100’s performance as monotherapy verses placebo.
Algela/Bayer’s ALSYMPCA Phase III programme was also presented. When discussing the subgroup data, Dr Gschwand commented on lower efficacy with poor ECOG score patients
The presentation ended with a multidisciplinary discussion on a few patient case studies
Highlights from the Astellas Symposium
Astellas appears to be already branding MDV3100 with strap-lines such as “back to the future” and the high tech train imagery. The three trains could represent the three modes of action.
Hormonal therapy in early CRPC: Established target, new approaches.
A Heidenreich, Germany
Definitions, diagnosis and epidemiology of CRPC were discussed as well as the lack of evidence to show that traditional hormone therapies (anti-androgen, corticosteroid and ketoconazole) improve overall survival.
With the improved understanding of the underlying biology of CRPC including AR signaling, a new generation of pre-chemotherapies are emerging of which abiraterone, TAK 700 and MDV3100 were heralded as examples. With the emphasis being placed on MDV3100 and Astellas/Medivation PREVAIL & TERRAIN Phase II and III trials.
Case study and panel discussion.
N James, UK
An unusual case was presented which illustrated the difficulty in defining hormonal non-response with the panel and the audience repeatedly arguing that the patient being discussed should be convinced to be maintained on an androgen deprivation therapy. He has been treated intermittently with anti-androgen and oestrogens as monotherapy for the past 7 years. Dr James raised the question of newer agents being tested on top of a traditional hormone therapy baseline and could it be time for a rethink and consider monotherapy?
Envisioning the future of hormonal treatment of late-stage CRPC
C.N. Sternberg, Italy
In her introductions Dr Sternberg highlighted the increasing collaboration between radiologists, oncologists and urologists in managing CRPC, which is helping to pushing treatment and outcomes into a new era. The rapid expansion of current and likely future treatment options for CRPC was then highlighted
Dr Sternberg participated in the pivotal COU-AA-302 abiraterone trial and focused on abiraterone’s impressive hazard ratios across a wide range of subgroups. She did highlight the exception of patients with an ECOG status of 2. The same pattern is being observed in the abiraterone Expanded Access trial in which Dr Sternberg is taking part. A comparable adverse event profile to placebo was also highlighted.
Takaeda’s (Millennium) Orteronel TAK-700 Phase III was positioned as a similar molecular to abiraterone before going on to discuss MDV3100 post chemotherapy AFFIRM trial. The trial was introduced as having the best results of any agent studied to date on overall survival (37% reduction in death) combined with impressive sub-group hazard ratios and virtually the same adverse event profile as placebo.
The talk concluded with the question of how will these new agents be integrated into a treatment when only a few years ago once post chemotherapy hormone treatment had failed there was nothing? Dr Sternberg then went onto challenge docetaxel as being the therapy against which newer agents are positioned. Over the coming years answers will need to be found as to which agents to combine with chemotherapy, what is the optimal sequence of therapies and can a therapy be withdrawn?
Other data relating to MDV3100 includes Poster 235: Clusterin knockdown synergizes activity of second generation anti-androgen, MDV3100, through enhancing AR degradation and repression of FKBP52 in castrate resistant prostate cancer model. This study highlights the synergistic effect of Medivation’s MDV3100 and OncoGenex’s OGX-011 in combination. OncoGenex phase III Custirsen is also in combination with first line docetaxel (fast track status with FDA).
The CI Dept gratefully acknowledges coverage of the above meetings by Beth Elliott.

item.title: Aragon Raise Timely Financing
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: San Diego-based Aragon Pharmaceuticals has secured $42m of Series C cash through the Topspin Fund to continue the development of its prostate drug ARN-509 to POC.
Nature & Rational For Fund Raising
Based on some early indications of efficacy the biotech has married up with a nontraditional investor to raise financing for a POC study. The Topspin Fund, headed by one-time hedge fund wiz Jim Simons, put up half of the cash
ARN-509 has attracted a significant amount of buzz in the biotech field. The treatment was discovered by a team of scientists led by Charles Sawyer, a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator who is credited with the development of MDV3100.
Aragon needed the capital on a short timeline, since investigators were able to transition from a successful Phase I into a Phase II, enrolling about 100 late-stage patients in half the time initially projected.
Next Steps
The cash is expected to last about 2 years depends on whether a partnership is secured for phIII development. If it is then Aragon plans to swiftly change gears and turn the spotlight on its follow-up program for breast cancer as the partner moves forward on the prostate cancer drug.
There's also potential for a tie-up with a PI3 kinase inhibitor, which helped inspire Aragon's decision to ask Carol Gallagher, who helmed Callistoga and its PI3 kinase inhibitor program ahead of its sale to Gilead to sit on the company's board.
Source:www.aragon.com

item.title: Ph2 GVAX Prostate with Ipilimumab in Patients with mCRPC is Anticipated to Start this Year
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BioSante has announced the publication of the Ph1 results of its cancer vaccine in combination with ipilimumab in the current issue of the Lancet Oncology. A Ph2 is anticipated to begin this year at the Johns Hopkins Sidney Kimmel Comprehansive Cancer Center.
Protocol
Fixed doses of GVAX Prostate in combination with escalating 0.1, 0.3, 1.0, 3.0 and 5.0 mg/kg doses of ipilimumab.
Recruitment
  • 12 patients in 3 dose escalation cohorts
  • 16 patients in an expansion ipilimumab 3.0 mg/kg cohort
53% of patients achieving at least stable disease, with two patients showing clear regression of metastases.
In addition, 23% of patients in the higher dose cohorts had confirmed partial PSA responses of greater than 50% from baseline.
No serious AEs in tle lower dose ipilimumab cohorts and administration of immunotherpay was well tolerated in safe.
Titla: "Combined Immunotherapy with Granulocyte-Macrophage Colony-Stimulating Factor-Transduced Allogeneic Prostate Cancer cells and Ipilimumab in Patients with Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer. A Phase 1 Dose Escalation Trial" - The Lancet Oncology (February 2012).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Combination of Cabazitaxel and Abiraterone Enters Ph1 for mCRPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Investigator-Sponsored trial is being led by Dr Chris Sweeney at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and will assess the maximum tolerated dose of the combination in men with mCRPC who have disease progression following treatment with up to two prior chemotherapy regimens.
Cabozantinib is a potent inhibitor of MET, and may therefore enhance the activity of abiraterone by blocking this putative resistance mechanism.
Additionally, the high level of activity that cabozantinib has demonstrated against both soft tissue and bone lesions in men with CRPC may complement the clinical activity of abiraterone.
Design
Part A is a dose-escalation study in which patients will receive cabozantinib (20 mg, 40 mg, or 60 mg) in combination with 1000 mg of abiraterone daily and 5 mg of prednisone twice daily. This part of the study is a standard “3 plus 3” dose-escalation design in which 3 patients are initially accrued at each dose level. If none of the patients experiences a dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) in the first 4 weeks of treatment, dose escalation will proceed to the next dose level. If 1 patient experiences a DLT, 3 additional patients will be accrued at that dose. If 2 or more patients experience a DLT, that dose will be considered as exceeding the MTD.
Part B of the study, the dose levels identified as safe and tolerable in Part A will be expanded to include up to 12 patients.
Primary Endpoint
Rate of dose limiting toxicity (DLT) in the first 4 weeks of therapy when abiraterone is combined with escalating doses of cabozantinib.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: PWC's 15th Annual Global Pharma & Life Sciences CEO Survey
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: PWC has recently published the outcome of its annual survey of 82 pharma and life sciences CEOs in 29 countries to understand how businesses are preparing for growth in their priority markets.
Key Findings
  • Only 34% of all CEOs – and only 22% of those running pharma and life sciences companies – plan to make strategic alterations as a result of changes in risk tolerance over the next 12 months.
  • Only 12% believe the global economy will pick up this year. But 45% are very confident of being able to generate higher revenues over the next 12 months, and 49% are very confident of being able to do so over the next three year
  • CEO's are refashioning their business models for a world where the opportunities and threats are increasingly interconnected but the sources of growth are often local.
  • 66% of all pharma and life sciences CEOs plan to make other strategic alterations over the next 12 months. And 21% of them anticipate making fundamental changes, in contrast with the overall average of just 13%
  • The ability to hire, develop, and retain talent in the developing economies has become a major point of competitive differentiationtalent constraints have restricted innovation in 33% of pharma and life sciences companies, and 45% have seen their labour costs climb more than expected.
  • 49% of pharma and life sciences CEOs are turning to technology to address the skill shortage. Eli Lilly, for example, has invested heavily in computational analysis and cloud computing to improve the productivity of its research team.
Thanks to Alison Attard (SIS) a link to a copy of the full report is shown below:-

pwc.com/gx/en/ceo-survey/pdf/15th-global-ceo-survey-pharmaceuticals-life-sciences.pdf

item.title: Neurosearch Makes Progress Towards FDA Submission
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NeuroSearch has completed enrollment of 118 patients in the open-label, North American Phase II Open-HART trial evaluating 45 mg twice-daily Huntexil. Last year, the FDA indicated that additional clinical data would be needed to support an NDA submission following a meta-analysis which showed a significant improvement in UHDRS on therapy at 26 weeks.
The trial is an extension to the Phase IIb HART study. In 2010, the company reported data from HART showing that Huntexil missed the primary endpoint of significantly improving voluntary motor function as measured by the change from baseline in the modified motor score subscale of the UHDRS vs. placebo at week 12.
In December 2010, NeuroSearch reported data from a meta-analysis of HART and Phase III MermaiHD trial, showing that Huntexil non-significantly improved voluntary motor function by 0.6 points as measured by the modified motor score (mMS) subscale of the UHDRS vs. placebo at week 12 but significantly improved the endpoint by 1.2 points at week 26.
Scource: neurosearch.com

item.title: MOVIPREP Filed in Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ajinomoto, Norgine's Japanese Partner, have filed an application in Japan for the manufacture and marketing authorisation of MOVIPREP, which will be used for bowel preparation prior to colonoscopy.
Ajinomoto markets Niflec® which is used for cleaning the bowel prior to colonoscopy. However it expects that MOVIPREP, with its reduced dosage volume will contribute to improving patient’s quality of life.

The drug is injected by a urologist in an office setting directly into the zone of the prostate where the enlargement occurs and involves little or no pain or discomfort.
Recruitment: approx. 150 men
Protocol: two dose 6 week Phase 2 study designed in accordance with specific direction and guidance provided by the FDA in Pre-IND meetings.
On Feb 21, 2012 the company announced the start of activities aimed to the preparation of a EU Ph3 clinical trial, following the successful completion of a Scientific Advice meeting with the EMA.
A Ph3 is currently in clinical development in the U.S.

item.title: TAK-700 Data Suggests Side Effects Could Be An Issue
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: TAK-700 PhII data suggests that its side effect profile is far from being benign, Whilst the company is claiming that it is feasible to use the drug without concomitant prednisone, the data suggests this may not be applicable to the majority of non-metastatic patients with a rising PSA (the study group evaluated).
Study Design
  • Eligible men in the phII study had baseline PSA ≥2ng/mL and surgical or ongoing medical castration, with testosterone <50ng/dL.
  • Prior chemotherapy, aminoglutethimide or ketoconazole, or concomitant corticosteroids were excluded.
  • Starting dose of TAK-700 was 300mg BID given continuously in 28-d cycles, optionally increasing to 400mg BID if ≥50% decrease in PSA (PSA50) was not achieved after 3 mo.
  • TAK-700 was continued until PSA progression or metastases.
  • The study primary endpoint was the percentage of men with PSA ≤0.2ng/mL after 3 mo.
  • Secondary endpoints include safety, 3 and 6 mo PSA30, PSA50, PSA90 rates, progression-free survival, time to PSA progression, time to metastases, changes in endocrine markers and circulating tumor cell (CTCs).
  • 38 men with a median age 71 y (range 55-81), ECOG PS 0/1 (84%/16%), median PSA 12.5ng/mL (2.6-67.8), testosterone 0.267nmol/L (0.05-0.60), and ACTH 19.5ng/L (n=32; 0-47) were treated.
  • Median number of cycles was 5.5 (1-13); 1 patient had dose reduction due to adverse events (AEs), 1 had dose increase to 400mg BID. 99% of the total planned dose was taken
Key Efficacy Results
  • At 3 mo, 4 men (11%) achieved PSA ≤0.2ng/mL. PSA50 and PSA90 rates were 69% and 28%, respectively.
  • At 3 mo, median PSA decline was 83% to 1.96ng/mL (n=28; 0.12-50.5); median testosterone declined by 89% to 0.026nmol/L (0-0.28), and median ACTH increased by 228% to 55ng/L (12-351).
  • Similar results were seen at 6 mo, with changes of –87% to 2.05ng/mL (0.1-12.3), –86% to 0.033nmol/L (0.01-0.41), and +312% to 83.5ng/L (21-173), respectively. 6-mo PSA50 and PSA90 rates were 42% and 17%, respectively. 14 men (37%) were on treatment >6 mo.
  • Of 35 men with baseline CTC/7.5mL values, only 1 had CTC ≥5 and 6 had 1-4 CTC.
Toxicity Issues
Gr ≥3 AEs occurred in 16 men (drug-related in 13); most common (≥5%) were dyspnea (11%), hypertension (8%), fatigue, hypokalemia, pneumonitis (5% ea).
Seven men (18%) had serious AEs; most common was pneumonitis (2=Gr3, 1=Gr2).
Eight men discontinued ortl due to AEs (dyspnea, pneumonitis, adrenal insufficiency, fatigue, hypertension, diarrhea, dysgeusia).
EAU Abstract 124

item.title: Update on Leuprorelin Hybrid in Poland
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Thanks to our colleagues Robert and Jurek () we have learnt that Sandoz' Leuprostin did not get reimbursement status in Poland.
Medical reps have been working with the product for two months now.
Although intensive efforts deployed by Sandoz, the Polish authorities did not recognize sufficient evidence in the scientific papers.
For that reason, Leuprostin did not obtain reimbursement status in the second update of the reimbursement list for 2012.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medivation Management Provides Insights on Ongoing Trials with MDV3100
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside financial results for Q4 2011, management reported S&GA continued to grow to almost 30% in anticipation of a MDV3100 commercial launch. If MDV3100 receives marketing approval, Medivation will provide 50% of the sales and medical affairs support for MDV3100 in the US. Regarding a new breast cancer indication for MDV3100, the company announced it will "get into clinical as quickly as it can".
Enrolment completed (67 men with advanced cancer who have not yet undergone chemical castration with LHRH analogs. The primary endpoint is PSA response).
Data of the six month study to be presented at "an upcoming meeting".
Recruitment is about 370 advanced prostrate cancer patients who have progressed following medical castration with LHRH analog therapy or surgical castration.
Management outliners that this trial "will be useful to gain market access both in the US and EU".
Enrolment of approx 1,670 patients will be larger than the Zytiga 302 study. Regarding the interim analysis, management iindicated they "intend to sit tight and see what Zytiga is going to do, and make the very best plan for MDV3100".
David Hung (President & CEO) noted that the company is "trying to expand 3100 to upstream indications" and "have three other trials ongoing", and "are also interested in expanding MDV3100 to other indications, and breast cancer is certainly one possibility".
Other internal programs are being assessed, and not all in cancer.
Management noted that "For 3100, as you know we licensed MDV3100 from That included a stable of about 170-plus compounds, all part of something called the RD series. And so those are all potential -- those are similar structures based on the same scaffold and several of them are potential backups to 3100".
Medivation expects to to receive $45 million in development milestone payments in 2012 under the Astellas collaboration based on the assumption that marketing applications for MDV3100 in post chemotherapy patients will be filed in both the US and Europe and that the US NDA will be approved in 2012.
These 3 events would trigger milestone payments of $10 million, $5 million and $30 million, respectively.
The company is required to share 10% of any such development milestone payments received with

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma Snags Leader In Stem Cell Therapy For $200M
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dainippon Sumitomo has made a major move into the stem cell therapy arena acquiring Boston Biomedical for an upfront of $200m with a promise of another $2.43bn in milestones if Boston's two cancer candidates BB1608 and BB1503 are commercialised.
Development Status & Timelines
DSP currently aims to commercialize BBI608 and BBI503 in 2015 or later.
Both drugs are oral small molecule inhibitors of cancer stem cells.
BBI608 is currently in the preparatory stage for a Phase III trial in colorectal cancer in North America and in Phase Ib and II trials for various solid tumors. BBI503 is in a Phase I trial in North America involving patients with various advanced solid tumors. It is competing in the stem cell therapy space with companies such as Versatem and OncoMed Pharma (see Oncology7677: Verastem's Technology Overcomes Signficant Stem Cell Challenge).
DSP previously signed an exclusive product option license agreement with BBI in March 2011 on the rights of development and commercialization of BBI608 in Japan for all cancer indications.
Commenting on the acquisition Masayo Tada President and CEO of DSP stated:-The acquisition of BBI is not only an acquisition of an innovative pipeline in the oncology area, it also represents obtaining an excellent drug discovery and development platform with the capabilities of BBI, enabling us to continuously create candidate compounds likely to advance into later development stages".
“Subsequently" he noted "we intend to establish our R&D base in the U.S. to expand our presence in cancer treatment globally. We are aiming to make the oncology area one of our future focus therapeutic areas next to the CNS area.”
Scource. bosstonbiomedical…

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Patients Enrollment Started with Leuplin ® 6M in Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Two Ph3 trials that have been started are multicenter, randomized, open-label, comparative studies, with patients with prostate cancer and those with premenopausal breast cancer. The primary endpoints for prostate cancer is the suppression rate of serum testosterone to castrate level, and those for premenopausal breast cancer is the suppression rate of serum estradiol to menopausal level
Each trial is planned to enroll approx. 160 patients to evaluate safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and hormone dynamics of the medicine.
The 6M depot is currently available in United States and Europe.
Takeda is looking to strengthen its Leuplin geographical roll-out.
The company is investing in the hormone dependent cancer portfolio with the development of :
  • TAK-700 Non-steroidal androgen synthesis inhibitor (Ph3 US/EU/Jpn)
  • TAK-385 LHRH antagonist (Ph1 Jpn)

item.title: re: Update on Abbott's Procrin 6M in Spain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
We have been informed that Procrin 6M might be launched in January 2012 in Spain. Price will be 491.88€ (same as Decapeptyl). Contribution from Ipsen Spain is greatefuly acknowledged. 
It has been published new information in PM Pharma (IberoAmerican Pharmaceutical Marketing Portal).
“Abbott has announced the commercialization in Spain of the new presentation of Procrin (leuprolide acetate) in the treatment of hormone-dependent advanced prostate cancer.
The new formulation of Procrin, a 6 months presentation, contains 30 mg of leuprolide acetate. In addition, it has also changed the method of administration replacing the current format (syringe and vial) by a pre-filled syringe, the first in the market in a biannual presentation.
The transition from intramuscular to subcutaneous allows their use in patients on anticoagulants. This new delivery device, containing 1 ml injection volume, is easy to reconstitute and does not require special storage conditions.
Not only there is a new commercialization of the semestral presentation of Procrin but also the harmonization of the other leuprolide acetate Procrin presentations in Spain, monthly and quarterly, with the new 3.75 mg and 11.25 mg, respectively. The new syringe of subcutaneous administration is also applicable to these new doses.”

item.title: Tongyang Securities Reports on Medy-Tox Earnings
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In the domestic market, average sale price of Meditoxin fell 20% in early 2011 due to the launch of Hugel's Botulax in Korea (3Q10). Overseas sales decreased in 2011 as Medy-Tox stopped exportation in Brazil, where its partner Bergamo was sold to Amgen. The company is seeking potential partner for its next-generation toxin.
Medy-Tox plans to market existing product Meditoxin in Korea and developing countries, and sell the next-generation version of Meditoxin in advanced countries.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: A Selection of Urology Toxin Data Presented @ the EAU2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Several posters and abstracts highlighted new urological toxin results. During a poster presentation, it was reported that regardless of concomitant anticholinergics (AC) use, significant improvements in UI symptoms, urodynamics, and QOL were seen in OnabotA-treated patients with UI due to NDO, indicating that onabotA alone can be used in pts who do not respond to AC (Allergan sponsored study). During the 'Souvenir session by the EAU Scientific Congress Office' Prof. Francisco Cruz outlined 2 important studies. One focused on the Zurich experience including 10 year results with 100 U injections of botulinum-A in the detrusor muscle for OAB, and another on the safety and efficacy of using a reduced dose of OnabotA (200 U) in 46 MS patients previously treated with higher doses (300 U).
Poster 461 - Efficacy of OnabotulinumtoxinA in Neurogenic Detrusor Overactivity Is Independent of Concomitant Anticholinergic Use
Results were pooled from 2 pivotal, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled phase 3 studies with identical entry criteria and treatments (Double-blind InvestiGation of purified Neurotoxin complex In neurogenic deTrusor overactivitY (DIGNITY) program: studies 191622-515 (NCT00311376) and 191622-516 (NCT00461292).
Abstract 692 - Experiences including 10 year results of 253 Cases treated with low-dose (100 U) Botulinum-A Toxin Injections in the Detrusor Muscle for Overactive Bladder refractory to Anticholinergics
Abstract 464 - Does dose reduction of Botulinum toxin-A affect quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis?

item.title: Esmya(R) Granted EMA for Uterine Fibroids
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The EC has granted marketing authorization to Richter/PregLem's Esmya(R) 5mg tablet for pre-operative treatment of moderate to severe symptoms of uterine fibroids.
This decision follows positive opinion from the CHMP for the EMA on December 2011 (see Oncology7967: Richter/PregLem's Esmya® Receives Positive Opinion from the EMA/CHMP).
Esmya is now commercially available in the UK from Preglem at a price of £114.13 for 28 5mg tablets.

Comments
Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3 trial which is to evaluate the sustained efficacy and safety of long term on-off treatment with Esmya (5 or 10mg doses) on uterine bleeding, myoma size, pain and quality of life.
Start date: June 2012 - Completion date: April 2015/June 2015
Recruitment: Approx. 600 pre-menopausal women with symptomatic uterine myoma(s) characterised by heavy bleeding
Locations: 13 EU countries
Source: NCT01629563
The Scottish Medicines Consortium (SMC) backed the use of Esmya on the NHS as the 1st oral treatment for uterine fibroids. The licence from the SMC means the drug ca now be prescribed generally in treatment.
The EMA has positively assessed Richter's application to extend the indication of its Esmya tablets to the long-term treatment of symptoms of uterine fibroids. The Agency's positive opinion would be forwarded to the European Commission, which is expected to amend the marketing authorisation for Esmya for all countries of the European Union, within two months.

Esmya's initial EU marketing licence was for the pre-operative treatment of moderate-to-severe symptoms of uterine fibroids in adult women.

"The extension of indication to include the repeated intermittent treatment will give, should it be approved, the opportunity to many women suffering from this condition to be relieved from the symptoms of fibroids," Richter said in a statement on the Budapest bourse's website.
Following a positive opinion from the Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) on 23 April 2015 EC has granted approval for a label extension of Esmya 5mg, which now adds the intermittent treatment courses. This is applicable for all Member States in the European Economic Area.
This will provide an opportunity to women to benefit from long term medical management of uterine fibroids and potentially avoid surgery. This also means more choice for physicians.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Uptake of Provenge Begins to Taper Off
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dendreon's shares fell by nearly 19 percent yesterday after the company said it expects sales growth for Provenge to moderate in the first quarter to low single digits, based partly on fewer new patient enrollments.

Revenue from the product was $77 million for the fourth quarter, up from $25 million in the corresponding period a year ago and pulling slightly ahead of the $76 million anticipated by analysts.

Total fourth-quarter revenue was $202 million, boosted by a $125 million payment for Dendreon’s sale of its royalty interest in Merck’s Victrelis hepatitis C treatment. The royalty helped Dendreon post a fourth-quarter profit of $38.1 million, up from a loss of $91.8 million in the year earlier period.

Uptake of Provenge

Dendreon claims to be making progress with the insurance reimbursement issues that had hampered Provenge’s financial performance following its introduction in 2010.

Looking ahead, management reiterated plans to expand sales of Provenge, reduce manufacturing costs and advance the company’s pipeline of experimental drugs.

It noted that its European application has now been validated and that it needs to begin to enter that market and enrollment is also well underway for our study examining the sequencing of abiraterone and PROVENGE in androgen deprivation therapy in men with a rising PSA after primary therapy, especially important in the urology setting. Urology has been our fastest growing segment of the business and is viewed as a very important segment of the business for Dendreon moving forward. Currently urology is about 20% of the business, oncology 80% .

item.title: Key Messages from Astellas' Sympo on OAB @EAU2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The sympo aimed to explore current and future trends in the management of OAB, identify the current needs of OAB patients, and look to the new prescribing agents on the horizon.
Non-Adherence to Medication
According to Astellas market research between 30 and 50% of patients do not adhere to their prescribed treatments irrespective of disease or prognosis.
Medication non-adherence results in increased clinical risk and therefore in increased morbidity and mortality.
Non-adherence along with suboptimal diagnosis, prescribing and medication administration costs £290 billion/year in the U.S
To improve adherence with antimuscarinic drug therapy, it is necessary to improve patient information (about their condition and their treatment), to assess the individual wishes and concerns of patients, and understand more about the correct regimen for OAB drug therapy.
- Antimuscarinics remain the mainstay of OAB treatment but patient adherence levels demonstrate a need for alternative therapies.
- beta3-adrenoreceptor agonists are currently in development, and have different mechanism of action compared to antimuscarinics.
  • Ph3 studies with mirabegron
- Therapies such as neuromodulation and botulinum toxin do not require patient motivation to be effective.
Also See Neurology6261: New iOAB Drug Demonstrates Better Efficacy Than Standard Of Care

item.title: Key Messages from the Ferring Sympo @ EAU2012
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: New emerging therapies and more data becoming available represent a challenge for established practices. Evidence to support neoadjuvant/adjuvant/intermittent ADT, optimal sequencing and drug combinations for the treatment of CRPC remain to be established. A preview of the CS30 trial comparing degarelix to goserelin + bicalutamide in the neoadjuvant setting was presented by Prof. Malcom Mason. At the end of the symposium, the takehome messages from Pf Montorsi outlined that degarelix is an effective 1st-line ADT with tangible benefits for patients, and that results in first study in intermittent ADT are promising.
Malcom Mason (Professor of Clinical Oncology and Director of the Institute of Cancer & Genetics art Cardiff University’s School of Medicine) introduced his session in outlining that neoadjuvant HT before RT can improve disease control and/or survival versus RT alone (Payne & Mason Br J Cancer 2011:105:1628-34).
Pf M Mason selected 2 trials demonstrating the importance of neoadjuvant HT (NADHT).
RTOG8610: Neoadjuvant HT (4 months) + RT Vs RT alone
10-year results show that neoadjuvant HT significantly improved disease-specific mortality and measures of disease control, but not OS or median survival time.
TROG96.01: Neoadjuvant HT (3 or 6 months) + RT Vs RT alone
10-year results show a high difference in OS in favor of 6-month NADT. Other outcomes show that 3- and 6- month ADT significantly improved PSA, local progression and event-free survival. 6-month ADT also significantly improved distant progression an PCa mortality (Denham et al. Lancet Oncol 2011:12:451-9).
He indicated that robust data show that adjuvant HT + RT can significantly improve progression and/or OS in high-risk PCa vs RT or ADT alone (Payne & Mason Br J Cancer 2011 105:1628-34).
Optimum treatment duration with neoadjuvant HT remains a big question
Optimum treatment duration with adjuvant HT
Selecting the right patient is important
.
This was a randomised, parallel-arm, active-controlled, open-label, multi-centre trial on 182 patients treated with either monthly degarelix (240/80 mg) or goserelin (3.6 mg) for 12 weeks. For effective flare protection, goserelin-treated patients also received daily bicalutamide (50 mg) during the initial 28 days.
Key trial parameters monitored monthly were TPV (primary endpoint), serum testosterone, prostate-specific antigen (PSA), the International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS), IPSS QoL and the BPH Impact Index.
Non-inferiority for the primary endpoint was considered to be established, if the treatment difference in adjusted mean percentage reduction was significantly greater than Δ = ‑10 points in both the FAS and PP analyses sets (two-sided at α=0.05 level).
Degarelix is non inferior to goserelin + bicalutamide.
Secondary endpoint
Decreases in IPSS were more pronounced in degarelix versus goserelin-treated patients, differences being statistically significant in patients with moderate/severe LUTS.
In conclusion, Pf Mason reported that ADT + RT is now the standard of care for patients with locally advanced PCa (Heidenreich et al. 2011). The combination of ADT plus RT prevents death from prostate cancer, and delays disease progression. Significant improvement in symptom control with neoadjuvant degarelix vs GnRH agonist, without need for flare protection. Last but not least, he highlighted that a multi-disciplinary approach involving urologist and oncologists is key (Valadagni et al. Eur J Cancer 2011:47;1-7).
Peter Albers (Professor and Chairman of the Department of Urology at the U. of Düsseldrof, Germany) focused his talk on IAD and CAD. He selected 2 Ph3 trials in locally advanced or metastatic PCa:
  • SEUG9401 (Calais da Silva FM et al. J Clin Oncol 2006 24 (185) 4513 Calais da Silva FEC et al. Eur Urol 2009 55:1269-77) SWOG9346 (Hussain M et al. J Clin Oncol 2006 24:3984-90)
Respective results are provided below :
Can those results be transferred to patients with PSA relapse ?
In summary,
  • IAD is non-inferior to CAD in patients with PSA relapse
  • All QoL parameters in patients with IAD are improved
  • Details o IAD are still unclear (PSA cut-off, re-start cut-off).
In summary for clinical practice:
  • Similar efficacy outcomes with IAD and CAD
  • EAU prostate cancer guidelines 2011: IAD no longer experimental
  • Benefits regarding potency, QoL improvements possible
  • Recommended in patients with locally advanced disease and/or PSA relapse after curative treatment (long life expectancy)
Regarding IAD with a GnRH antagonist, Pf Albers reported that:
  • no published studies as yet
  • it remains unclear whether LHRH agonist monotherapy may be used as IAD
  • a GnRH antagonist “might be a valid alternative, provided clear results are obtained from randomized trials”.
Interim data available for 213 patients in the first study of degarelix as IAD (CS29) was presented:
PSA and testosterone recovery demonstrated
Sexual function tends to improve in off-period
In summary, Pf Albers outlined that degarelix is suitable for IAD. However, questions remain:
  • Induction phase — how long ?
  • Survival benefit over LHRH agonists ?
  • QoL benefit over LHRH agonists ?
Francesco Montorsi (Professor of Urology at U. Vita-Salute San Raffaele, Milan) dedicated his session to the pharmacology of GnRH agonists and antagonists, the comparison of the efficacy and the safety of agonists vs antagonists.
He highlighted that approx. 2000 patients in total in the US, Canada, EU and South America were included in studies to compare degarelix vs GnRH agonists.
A review of the most significant results of the CS21 and CS21a trials was presented.
Of note, for:
PSA PFS for degarelix vs leuprolide in Baseline Gleason > or equal to 8
Tme to first CV event in PCa patients with no manifest CV event disease at baseline
Lower risk of CV events for degarelix vs GnRH agonists in patients with established CV disease
Implications for patients
Compared with GnRH agonist therapy, degarelix offers:
  • No risk of clinical flare
  • Longer time to CRPC, and therefore initiation of second-line treatment
  • Better tumour control, and a delay in time to death or progression over 7 months
  • Improved control of skeletal mets and less bone pain
  • Potential for improved LUTS control in more symptomatic patients
  • Patients with a history of CVD are at lower risk of another CV event when treated with degarelix vs leuprolide
Neal Shore (Medical Director for the Carolina Urologic Research Center, USA) focused on new approaches when castration is not enough. Mechanism of action as well as the latest results of Cabazitaxel, abiraterone, and MDV3100 were presented.
Regarding immunotherapy for CRPC, Dr Shore noted the improved OS with sipuleucel-T, and PROSTVAC. He also cited Ipilimumab and tremelimumab that potentiate T-cell responses. Other agents such as denosumab and Radium-223 were part of the presentation. A table with other investigational agents was presented.
The future of mCRPC
Implications for patients

item.title: 2011 A Good Year For The Venture Capital Community
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: At this week's CI In Pharma Summit in Zurich a very interesting overview of trade sales in pharma was presented by the private equity group HBM Partners. The group has recently published an updated report detailing all completed trade sales of North American and European specialty pharma, generics, OTC and traditional pharma companies since 2005.
Key 2011 Findings
  • 2011 was a strong year for pharma/biotech M&A with transaction volume totalling $64.9bn in value (excluding the Pharmasset purchase by Gilead).
  • The number of M&A deals at 71 was on a par with previous years albeit those where the upfront consideration was at least $100m accounted for a record number (38).
  • Deal activity was most prominent during the first half of the year due to the purchase of Genzyme by Sanofi and Nycomed by Takeda. The latter also resulted in a record volume for VC/PE backed company trade sales.
  • Average multiples for VC-backed company sales jumped to 2.8x so 2011 will be remembered as a good year for the venture capital community.
A copy of the full report is attached for review.

item.title: FDA Panel Recommends US Approval Of Chelsea's Northera
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Chelsea Therapeutics received a positive FDA recommendation that its drug Northera (droxidopa) should be approved for the treatment of symptomatic neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (NOH), a condition most frequently found amongst Parkinson disease patients.
Panel Vote
The vote despite critical pre-meeting documentation was 7-4 in favour of approval. FDA reviewer Melanie Blank was concerned about a possible link between the drug's usage and neuroleptic malignant syndrome. However, panel members voted in favour saying that the drug's benefits outweigh its risks because there are so few treatments for NOH and the risks are not unpredictable.
Commercialisation Plans
During its November earnings call, Chelsea management noted that amongst the first things it would do in the New Year was to hire ten regional sales directors, and then it would look to recruit and secure approximately 85 specialty sales reps on a conditional basis. It was working with a vendor at that time to provide logistical support in sales force operations, needed not only to transition into a commercial organization, but to do so successfully over a relatively short period of time. It felt that this approach offered the company the ability to scale up rapidly while limiting internal infrastructure and head count costs.
The Current Market/ Treatment Opportunity In Parkinson's Disease

The market consists primarily of two drugs used to treat NOH: midodrine and fludrocortisone. It is estimated that of the approximately 180,000 patients that suffer from symptomatic NOH in the U.S., about 80,000 to 85,000 of them take midodrine while another 80,000 to 90,000 takes fludrocortisone, a sympathetic adrenal corticosteroid that works by increasing sodium retention enhancing plasma volume, and thereby raising blood pressure.

The Parkinson's market is perceived to offer the most significant growth opportunity because of the attention paid to the non-motor features of Parkinson's disease and the expanding no of 70 and 80-year olds with the disease. While some of these patients do receive treatment, the efficacy and, in particular the side effects profile of current drug therapy, has limited both utilization and compliance.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Swiss and German Pharma Majors Face Up to Increasing Debts in Crisis-Hit Southern Europe
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As the German edition of the Financial Times reports, Merck KGaA has implemented a policy of immediate payment on delivery, while Roche is reported to be planning to introduce a system whereby they only deliver products to hospitals within a specified credit limit. The countries concerned are Greece, Spain, and Italy, with the first two in the worst situation.
As the source reports, Merck KGaA had taken Greek government bonds with a nominal value of EUR56 million (USD74.1 million) to pay off hospital debts, but when the company sold these bonds, they received substantially less than this. In the mean time, it is reported that although the situation in Spain has not yet led to stops in supplies, Roche is considering this, reporting that in some cases, hospitals have not paid bills for three years. This is why Roche plans the introduction of a credit limit system in Spain and Portugal. Swiss newspaper Tagesanzeiger reports that Roche and fellow Swiss major Novartis have billions of euro of outstanding payments from hospitals in southern European countries.
The debt situation in Greece, Spain, and Italy is deteriorating, and in the case of Greece, although the focus remains on the bond payments, which resulted in considerable losses for pharmaceutical companies, the debt situation appears to be worsening again.
In Spain, total debts owed to pharmaceutical and medical device producers have been estimated at EUR12 billion, while in Italy, although there are significant regional variations, the situation is approaching that of Spain.
Although Greece is a smaller market and therefore less of a danger in terms of potential inability to pay, the prospect of this in Spain, and particularly Italy, is not one pharma companies would like to contemplate. Therefore, they will be hoping the austerity measures and measures to kick-start the economies of these countries will have the desired effects.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Leads the Way with its Cell-Based Assay for Botox(R) and Vistabel(R)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has received positive opinions from Agence Française de Sécurité Sanitaire des Produits de Santé (AFSSAPS) and the Irish Medicines Board (IMB) regarding its fully in vitro, cell-based assay. The European Coalition to End Animal Experiments (ECEAE) along with the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection (BUAV) have welcomed these new milestones.
The positive opinion from AFSSAPS relates to Vistabel(R), and paves the way for approval in 29 countries in the EU.
  • France serves as the Reference Member State covering 29 countries in the EU (Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Czec Rep., Cyprus, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luwxemburg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and the U.K)
The positive opinion from IMB relates to Botox(R) and covers 14 EU countries involved in the Mutual Recognition Procedure (MRP).
  • Ireland serves as the Reference Member State in the MRP; other countries involved are: Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Luxemburg, Norway, Portugal, Spain and Sweden).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Lexicon's Pipeline Progress With LX1032 & LX4211
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Alongside its Q4 figures, Lexicon provided some detailed comment on the status of its pipeline, highlighting how in the coming 12 months it has a number of very important results coming from each of its five key development programs.
LX1032 (Carcinoid Programme)
Lexicon is looking towards the end of the third quarter or early fourth quarter for initiation of the Phase 3 program providing regulatory interactions are supportive. It has a meeting with the FDA scheduled for last week of March/1st week of April and a meeting with the EMA this month.
Commenting on the potential design of the phIII carcinoid study Pablo Lapuerta stated:-
"we do have a protocol synopsis, and that envisions four months of therapy, which is consistent with some of the discussions we've had before with regulatory agencies. And the total sample size, we think that for an orphan drug indication like this that we can get meaningful safety and efficacy data with – on a ballpark of 100 patients. It could be slightly more or slightly less, but that's the type of area that we will be discussing with the FDA. We also feel that a reduction in bowel movement frequency is a clinically relevant measure and objective measure that's easy to interpret. And so that's what we are considering for our Phase 3 program, and we feel there is a precedent for that as well."
Management comments regarding the ulcerative colitis indication noted that the goal for 2012 is to establish some basic proof-of-concept data with an appropriate safety profile that would allow us to go further into development.
A study called PARSEC has been initiated, a Phase 2 study of the relationship between serotonin and efficacy in ulcerative colitis. 60 patients with mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis have been randomised to placebo or two different doses of telotristat etiprate and the treatment period will be eight weeks.
LX1032 will be given on top of mesalamine (standard of care for patients with ulcerative colitis). There will be several efficacy measures including the Mayo score, which is primarily a clinical assessment, colonoscopy, histology. Results are expected Q12013.
Takeda's Positive Results In Pivotal Ulcerative Colitis Trial
Status of the Diabetes Programme
Preparations are also underway for the phIII development of the diabetic drug LX4211, with the ambition to start this as of 1H2013 ideally with a partner on board. Phase 2b results are expected at the end of Q2. And so that is coming up here. That's a study of approximately 300 patients with type 2 diabetes and we are on track to have those results.
Source; www.lexicon.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Combining Ipilimumab and PROSTVAC® Might Result in Prolonged OS
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The scientific findings of the Ph1 dose escalation study, published in the Lancet Oncology, provide proof of concept that the combination of an immune checkpoint inhibitor with a therapeutic cancer vaccine is feasible, and might enhance the clinical efficacy of the combination treatment.
Although the Ph1 trial was small and non-randomized, the median overall survival (OS) of 34.4 months for the 30 patients treated raises the possibility that the combination ipilimumab and PROSTVAC® might result in prolonged OS.
In a randomized placebo-controlled Phase 2 study, PROSTVAC® demonstrated an 8.5-month improvement in median overall survival, in men with mCRPC.
Please see Oncology7885: PROSTVAC® Ph3 trial Opened at First Site in the U.S..

item.title: New Results with BioGaia's Lactobacillus Reuteri Protectis for the Treatment of Diarrhea
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Outcomes of the study showed that supplementation of Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis significantly reduced episodes of diarrhoea. Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis was particularly effective in children with lower nutritional status. The study will be published in Journal of Pediatrics. Dr Rina Agustina will also present the results at the International Symposium of Probiotics and Prebiotics in Pediatrics (IS3P) on 24 February 2012.
Design: six month long double-blind, placebo-controlled study
Recruitment: 494 healthy children aged one to six years
Regimen: low-lactose milk with or without Lactobacillus casei 431 or Lactobacillus reuteri DSM17938
Country: Indonesia
Primary endpoint: number and duration of acute diarrhoeal episodes
Secondary endpoints: number and duration of acute respiratory infections
- incidence of all diarrhoea episodes was significantly reduced by 32% in the group supplemented by Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis compared to placebo.
- in children with lower nutritional status (below median height and weight for the age group) Lactobacillus reuteri Protectis had significant effect on both WHO defined and all episodes of diarrhoea.

item.title: Ongoing Medicine Evaluations In Europe To Become More Transparent
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an important move towards greater transparency, the EMA will from the 1st March 2012 start to publish information on applications for centralised marketing authorisation for human medicines that it has received for evaluation.
This development follows the publication of recommendations on transparency of ongoing evaluations adopted by the European Medicines Agency and the Heads of Medicines Agencies in November 2010.

Currently, the Agency does not publish information on other types of medicines until it has issued an opinion at the end of the assessment procedure.

What Will Be Published

The Agency will publish the international non-proprietary names (INN) and therapeutic areas for all new innovative medicines under evaluation by the CHMP, along with information on the type of salt, ester or derivative of the active substance. For generic and biosimilar medicines, it will publish the INN and therapeutic area. It will only publish this information for medicines whose applications have been validated.

Frequency of Updates

Every month following the plenary meeting of the CHMP.

Next Steps

This initiative also prepares for the publication of agendas and minutes of the meetings of the Agency’s committees in the second half of this year.

Thanks to Ros Eijgenhuijsen for forwarding the information for inclusion in Traction.

source: http://www.ema.europa.eu/ema/index.jsp?curl=pages/news_and_events/news/2012/02/news_detail_001437.jsp&mid=WC0b01ac058004d5c1&jsenabled=true

item.title: E. Kremer Has Joined Astellas' New Global Medical Affairs Organization
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Dr Charlotte M. E. Kremer, MD, MBA will provide global leadership for medical excellence and a unified medical perspective across regions for the company's portfolio of products.
Dr Kremer's Bio
Most recently, Dr. Kremer held the position of Vice President, Therapeutic Area Head for Ophthalmology, PVD, Rare Diseases and Neuroscience at Pfizer. While at Pfizer, she successfully led and executed the clinical development and global medical strategy in these respective areas. Prior to joining Pfizer, Dr. Kremer held positions of increasing responsibility providing medical support, developing Phase IIIB/IV clinical trials, and initiating and directing a Medical Liaison program at Organon Pharmaceuticals, both in the Netherlands and in the United States

item.title: 1st Indication of Pasireotide Results In Acromegaly & NET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Intelligence from two sources, CI department sponsored external primary intelligence gathering and a neuroendocrinology training course organised by the Mexican Endocrinology Society have confirmed that pasireotide performed better than octreotide LAR in Novartis's first phIII study undertaken in acromegaly patients CSOM230C2305, EudraCT number: 2007-001972-36. NET data, by contrast, may not be as encouraging according to independent sources.
PhIII Acromegaly Data
Thanks to Harold Dumont (IC Product Manager for Somatuline) and information forwarded by Sarah Gerbaud in Mexico we have learnt that Professor Ashley Grossman presented some very preliminary data in Mexico showing to what extent pasireotide met its primary endpoint in the phIII trial.
The studies undertaken in 358 treatment naive patients evaluated response rate at 12 months both in terms of GH <2.5 ug/l and normalisation of IGF-1.
The sample size for the trial was calculated to detect an increase in response rate of 15% from an expected 20% in the octreotide LAR group to 35% in the pasireotide LAR group based on the outcome of Novartis's historical phIII octreotide LAR studies CSMS995B2401 and B2402.
Professor Grossman's slide noted that "The first interpretable results indicate that the primary endpoint was met".
Primary intelligence gathering conducted by the CI Dept has established that Novartis is moving forward quickly now with pasireotide based on the Cushing's approval in Europe and the outcome of the acromegaly study, with data on the 2305 study expected to be presented at ENDO in Houston in June. There may also be some biochemical control data presented at the ECE in May. One US investigator described the data as "quite exciting". There has been no mention so far as to the safety profile of the drug in acromegalics.
Apparently data is also available from the crossover study CSOM230C2402, EUDRACT 2009-016722-13, recruitment seemingly having been quicker in the non-responder than the naive patient population.
Submission for the acromegaly approval was initially planned for May but with data analysis still ongoing, intelligence suggests that the end of the year is more likely.
What about NET?
Whilst acromegaly may be moving forward, messages about the NET data set are a far more mixed, with the US study reportedly "kind of stuck" at the moment. Some European data is expected soon according to one investigator and whilst showing good subjective responses in terms of flushing and diarrhoea effects on biomarkers and tumour growth are not significant. Moroever, the side-effect profile vs octreotide LAR is significantly worse.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: FDA Has Placed a Clinical Hold on GTx' Capesaris for Advanced Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The clinical hold follows the Company's reports to the FDA of an increased risk of venous thromboembolic events in subjects treated with Capesaris at the doses studied (1000 mg and higher). The clinical hold affects the PhII loading dose finding clinical trial and its PhIIb maintenance dose finding clinical trial, as well as its PhII clinical trial in men with CRPC.
GTx believes there may be a path forward to develop Capesaris at lower doses to treat men with metastatic hormone sensitive prostate cancer or castration resistant prostate cancer.
The Company will work with the FDA to determine the appropriate course of action to evaluate Capesaris in these patient populations.
Please see Oncology7929: Data In Q112 Should Determine Whether GTx Has A Viable New 1st or 2nd Line Prostate Cancer Drug

J&J's Zytiga (abiraterone) Too Expensive for National Health Service (NHS) 
Comment:   ...
The All Wales Medicines Strategy Group has approved Zytiga (abiraterone acetate) for men with advanced castration resistant prostate cancer - specifically, Zytiga is indicated for use alongside with prednisone or prednisolone in adult men whose disease has progressed after a docetaxel-based chemotherapy regimen.
The AWMSG were able to approve abiraterone after assessing it as an end of life drug, meaning it will now be available on the NHS in Wales until NICE release their final guidance, which will override the AWMSG decision if abiraterone is rejected.

item.dc:creator: spoon

Asia Key Country for Allergan 
Comment: In an interview with Reuters, Management has reported that Allergan will rely less on the U.S for revenues in coming year, as its products gain wider acceptance in Asia, with China to be the main driver.  ...
Allergan has currently authorised 180 Chinese hospitals nationwide to use Botox, including the major facilities of Shanghai Huamei Aesthetic in Shanghai and the Zhuhai Luda Plastic Surgery Hospital in Guangdong province.
Ian Bell said that Allergan has deliberately focused on physician training, working in partnership with select hospitals in key cities in China, instead of making it available everywhere in China.
He added that a local production plant in China is not planned because Allergan's existing facilities can meet global demand.
Source: Scrip 20 February 2012
