item.title: Corcept's Korlym™ Gains FDA Approval For Cushing's
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA on Friday Approved Corcept's Korlym™ (mifepristone) 300 mg tablets as a once-daily oral medicine to control hyperglycemia secondary to hypercortisolism in adult patients with Cushing’s syndrome who have type 2 diabetes mellitus or glucose intolerance and have failed surgery or are not candidates for surgery. Corcept is continuing to look for a European partner.
Approval was granted on the PDUFA date for the first and only approved medication for Cushing's syndrome in the US. This is an important milestone for the company and an achievement given Novartis's pasireotide has yet to be approved. A resubmission for its approval will we understand be made within the coming weeks.
Korlym will be launched commercially in the US by May 1 through what the company describes as "a distribution system designed to support both patients and prescribers."
Corcept does not envisage that it will require a large sales force to reach out to the small number of endocrinologists who treat Cushing's patients The company has begun hiring Medical Science Liaisons to inform practitioners about the drug, which will be dispensed by the leading specialty pharmacy company CuraScript SP, a subsidiary of Express Scripts.
Korlym clinical trial investigator Amir Hamrahian, M.D., Department of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolism at the Cleveland Clinic said, “There are not many effective treatment options for patients with Cushing’s syndrome. Although surgery is standard first line treatment for the disease, it is not always successful and not all patients are candidates. As part of the clinical trial, I have used Korlym successfully and my patients continue to do well on the medicine. I’m excited to be able to continue using Korlym in these patients and others who need it. This medicine’s approval gives me a much needed tool to better treat patients.”
Clinical Trial Results Supporting FDA Approval
The clinical data supporting the FDA approval of Korlym resulted from an uncontrolled, open-label, multi-center, 24-week phase III study of 50 patients who had endogenous Cushing's syndrome and were either not eligible for or had relapsed from surgery and were either glucose intolerant (29 patients) or had hypertension (21 patients). Within the glucose intolerant group, 60 percent of patients had a greater than 25 percent reduction from baseline in the area under the curve in the oral glucose tolerance test. In this group, mean hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) was reduced from 7.4 percent to 6.3 percent. All 14 patients with above-normal HbA1C levels at baseline experienced reductions. Eight of these 14 normalized their HbA1C. Antidiabetic medications were reduced in seven of the 15 patients with diabetes mellitus type 2 and remained constant in the others.
Patients who responded to therapy were allowed enrollment in an extension trial. Eighty-eight percent of the patients who completed the trial chose to do so.
A peer-reviewed analysis of the study results will soon be published in a leading journal.
The table below illlustrates how Corcept compares with pasireotide in terms of efficacy.
The FDA has designated Korlym as an Orphan Drug for treatment of the clinical manifestations of endogenous Cushing’s syndrome as a results Corcept will have marketing exclusivity consistent with the FDA’s designation until February 2019.
As noted in its Q3 results Corcept is looking for a partner to commercialise the product in Europe (see Endocrinology6756: Corcept PDUFA For Cushing's Disease Set For February 2012) where the drug also has orphan drug status.
Source: www.corcept.com

item.title: New US Draft Guidance on Biosimilar Product Development
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The FDA has finally issued three draft guidance documents on biosimilar product development. These documents provide FDA’s current thinking on approaches to demonstrate that a proposed biological product is biosimilar to an FDA-approved biological product (the “reference product”) using the abbreviated pathway under section 351(k) of the Public Health Service Act (PHS Act).

Thanks to GRA (Katie Ruffle & Steve Scott) we have the summary below which provides a synopsis of the guidance issued.

Access to the relevant sections of the guidance can be obtained via the source link at the bottom of the article.

The abbreviated pathway was established by the Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act of 2009 (BPCI Act), enacted on March 23, 2010, as part of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. FDA is accepting public comment on these draft guidance documents. Instructions on how to submit comments will be announced in an upcoming Federal Register notice.

Guidance: Scientific Considerations in Demonstrating Biosimilarity to a Reference Product

This draft guidance is intended to assist sponsors in demonstrating that a proposed therapeutic protein product is biosimilar to a reference product for the purpose of submitting an application under 351(k) of the PHS Act (a 351(k) application) to the FDA.

  • Focuses on therapeutic protein products. FDA will consider multiple factors as part of the biosimilarity assessment, including, but not limited to, the product’s complexity, formulation, and stability; as well as usefulness of biochemical and functional characterizations.
    • The incorporation of these factors is risk-based and is affected by knowledge regarding various product characteristics including, for example, the mechanism of action, the product structure-function relationships, the clinical experience with the reference product, and the manufacturing process.
  • Describes the totality-of-the-evidence approach that FDA intends to use for review of biosimilar applications.
    • FDA intends to use a risk-based totality-of-the-evidence approach to evaluate all available data and information submitted in support of the biosimilarity of the proposed product. The type and amount of analyses and testing that will be sufficient to demonstrate biosimilarity will be determined on a product-specific basis.
    • FDA recommends sponsors use a stepwise approach in developing evidence to support a demonstration of biosimilarity, ensuring that development at each step evaluate the extent to which there is residual uncertainty regarding a demonstration of biosimilarity between the proposed and reference product, and identify next steps to address that uncertainty.
    • FDA will be able to provide meaningful advice on the scope and extent of necessary animal and human testing after a thorough review of data from structural and functional analyses. Additional animal and clinical studies should be tailored to address residual uncertainty regarding the biosimilarity between the two products to ensure such testing is appropriately targeted.
  • Recommends early consultation with the FDA. FDA anticipates that early discussions with FDA about product development plans will facilitate biosimilar development.

Guidance: Quality Considerations in Demonstrating Biosimilarity to a Reference Protein Product

This draft guidance provides an overview of analytical factors that may be relevant to assessing whether a proposed therapeutic protein product and a reference product are highly similar, as required for a determination of biosimilarity under the BPCI Act.

    • Discusses general scientific principles, including the importance of extensive analytical, physicochemical and biological characterization. Recommends that the type, nature, and extent of any differences between the proposed biosimilar product and the reference product, and the potential effect of any differences on the safety, purity, and potency of the proposed product should be clearly described and discussed by the sponsor in the 351(k) application.
    • Recognizes that advances in analytical sciences and manufacturing technology, including integration of Quality by Design approaches, may facilitate a “fingerprint”-like analysis of therapeutic protein products, and thus may provide appropriate bases for a more selective and targeted approach to subsequent animal and/or clinical studies to support a demonstration of biosimilarity.

Guidance: Biosimilars: Questions and Answers Regarding Implementation of the Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act of 2009

This draft guidance provides answers to common questions from sponsors interested in developing proposed biosimilar products, biologics license application (BLA) holders, and other interested parties regarding FDA’s interpretation of the BPCI Act. The question and answer format is intended to promote transparency and facilitate development programs for proposed biosimilar products by addressing questions that may arise in the early stages of development. The draft guidance will be posted on FDA’s Web site and will be updated to include additional Q&As as appropriate.

http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/HowDrugsareDevelopedandApproved/ApprovalApplications/TherapeuticBiologicApplications/Biosimilars/default.htm

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Amylin's Comments on Bydureon Uptake At Leerink & Swann H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Initial uptake of the weekly GLP-1 analogue Bydureon has been strong with data from Germany indicating that half of the patients are new to GLP-1 analogues. Lilly is currently still marketing the product in Europe whilst Amylin looks for a new partner.
Commenting on this development Mark G. Foletta Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Amylin Pharmaceuticals, Inc. noted
"It's very early in any of the launches of BYDUREON to draw any conclusions. But I think the metric that we really are going to continue to focus on is where are the patients coming from? We know that our competitor actually focuses on that as well and what we've seen is we think over half of the patients that are starting BYDUREON therapy in Germany are coming from a GLP-1 naive market. That's our goal, that's our strategy with a weekly therapy to be able to continue to grow this market."
"In our year-end call that showed the rate of growth as we were exiting 2011 being very rapid with the success of BYETTA and Victoza globally. And we believe this market continued to have legs and it's a good sign that in -- albeit a very fast reimbursement market, Germany that that's what we're seeing is actually there is market growth.
When questioned on what marketing messages are being successful Mark Folleta noted:-
"What we believe is working there and that we think will work in most markets is essentially our message with BYDUREON is it's continuous glucose control with one weekly dose. And we've actually tried to help folks imagine what this is like, this is the first therapy for type 2 diabetes that is not a daily therapy, whether oral or injectable and so you can imagine sitting whatever day you choose, market research says many will choose Sundays and that they will in the privacy of their home can take this injection and then they know that their diabetes through the technology of the microspheres in BYDUREON will be -- their glucose will be controlled throughout the week. That message resonates with physicians and that's a message that we're certainly going to carry into the U.S. market as well."
Regarding the development status of the suspension programme
This refers to either a weekly or a monthly exenatide formulation that wouldn't require reconstitution. Amylin indicated that it has had an end of phase 2 discussions with the FDA and that it expects phase 3 trials for the weekly form to start in the middle of the year and for the monthly form the target is 2013.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: J&J's Key Comments On Zytiga At The Leerink & Swann H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Key data from the Zytiga chemonaive CRPC trial is expected this year with a filing for approval expected before the year end. Comments on European growth and J&J's reaction to the MDV3100 data were also aired.
Commenting on developments in Europe and the importance of Zytiga
Sherilyn S. McCoy Vice Chairman, Johnson & Johnson stated
"We continue to watch Europe very closely. One of the things that we're seeing specifically in the Pharmaceutical group, while there are some challenges relative to the economic environment, we are seeing products like Incivo, Zytiga doing extremely well because they are truly differentiated. And so I think the message for us is continue to look at how we make a difference in healthcare and bring new differentiated medicines, and that's a way to manage it."
"Certainly I think there's going to continue to be pressure on environment and it's critically important that we show outcomes data, and show that we are in fact making a difference in public health if we want to get reimbursement support. So I think that we've looked at from the standpoint of it is challenging, but we need to be focus on innovation and differentiation."
Focusing specifically on prostate cancer and Zytiga and when questioned about the chemotherapy naive study Sherilyn McCoy noted:-
"So the pre-chemo data, what – it's dependent on events and we're waiting for overall survival. So it's likely sometime later this year is what we estimate, but again it's dependent on events."
When further pressed about the filing date, she confirmed that filing would take place post the results and hopefully this year.
When asked about the impact MDV3100 might have on Zytiga uptake McCoy commented:-
"Well, certainly Medivation has a study, it's very difficult to compare because the patient population is different. It's not clear to us whether – all the usage components, so whether they're using prednisone or not, because they weren't clear on that, so we can't compare head to head. We feel very good about Zytiga. We have terrific data from patients and from physicians. There's a comfort level with people using the product, very high market share, in post castrate resistant cancer amongst metastatic treatments. So very, very high share and we feel very good about it. Certainly we need to wait and see what the actual data says and understand a little bit more about their data information".

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Deutsche Bank Survey Evaluates Potential Impact of Merz' Xeomin in the U.S
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The high-volume physicians surveyed (12 dermatologists and 13 plastic surgeons) have indicated that prior to Xeomin’s introduction, on average, Botox accounted for approx. 74% of their procedures and Dysport for approx. 26%. After the initial major discounting period ends, the group, on average, indicated that they plan to use Botox in approx 64% of patients, Dysport in 22%, and Xeomin in 14%. Key messages are provided below.
- to learn how they viewed Xeomin relative to Botox and Dysport.
12 dermatologists and 13 plastic surgeons with high-volume cosmetic neurotoxin practices and experience with Xeomin were surveyed.
Many doctors indicated that they liked the fact that Xeomin did not need to be refrigerated.
Price, a key factor
Two-thirds of the respondents said price was a major factor in their decision to use Xeomin.
Approx. half indicated that the price was significantly lower relative to Botox and Dysport.
With respect to efficacy and side effects, Xeomin is comparable to both Botox and Dysport.
Full report is attached

  • Recruitment: Approx 100 women >20 years old
  • Arms: low; medium and high dose
The first Ph2 was initiated in July 2011 in approx 20 participants to assess low and high dose of KLH-2109

item.title: Novartis to Increase Investments in Taiwan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The Taiwan Economic News today reported that Novartis will invest >NT$150M in Taiwan in 2012, with the objective of making the country its 10th clinical test center in the world.
Chang Chen-wu, President of the Novartis' Asian operation, outlined that the majority of the clinical tests will be conducted at National Taiwan University Hospital and 4 other domestic mmedical centres.
Novartis will undertake approx. 100 clinical tests in Taiwan in 2012 (Vs. 70 in 2011).
Most of the clinical tests in Taiwan are related to cancer drugs, with others including medicines in the fields of hematology, metabolism, and cardiology.

item.title: NICE Needs Additional Evidence for the Use of Botox(R) for Chronic Migraine
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: UK was the first country to approve Botox(R) in Q3 2010 for the prevention/prophylaxis of headaches in adults who have chronic migraines. NICE wants Allergan to provide better data before making a final guidance for the NHS in June. This issue might be discussed by Management during its R&D Technology review on March 28th.
Discussion of the results > see Neurology4935: Allergan Presents Migraine Data at the AAN Meeting.
NICE has estimated the cost would be £349.40 for every 12-week cycle of treatment.
Source: Nice PR http://www.nice.org.uk/newsroom/pressreleases/BotulinumToxinTypeAChronicMigraineACD.jsp

item.title: China : AZ Invests on a US$200Mn Manufacturing Center in JiangXu
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment : The British drug maker AZ has begun construction on a US$200 million manufacturing center in the eastern city of Taizhou (JiangXu).
The center, which is the largest investment that the company has made in a single facility worldwide, is expected to generate annual sales revenues of US$950 million after the facility opens in 2013.
Astra-Zeneca's substantial investment indicates that the company anticipates an increased demand for medical products in Jiangsu.
Since first establishing a presence in China in 1993, AstraZeneca has fast become one of the leading biopharmaceutical companies in the country, with a turnover of more than $1 billion in 2010. The new manufacturing facility reinforces AZ's long term commitment to the country and its contribution to the Chinese economy.
AZ's direct investments in local capabilities to help deliver innovative medicines to Chinese patients and healthcare services to physicians include:
  • A state-of-the-art manufacturing and supply site in Wuxi New District, Jiangsu Province;
  • The AstraZeneca Innovation Centre China (ICC) — a leading-edge translational science centre targeting, among others, biomarker research into cancer therapies specifically relevant for Chinese and Asian patients. The ICC is one of AstraZeneca’s most advanced scientific research hubs outside the UK, Sweden and US;
  • An established sales and marketing operation;
  • Large scale clinical development capabilities and,
  • An extensive network of collaborations with leading academic and medical institutions.
Source : Frontier Strategy Group (Jan 2012)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Promising New Approach To The Treatment Of Huntington's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Medical researchers at the University of Alberta have discovered a promising new treatment approach for Huntington's disease that restores lost motor skills and may delay or stop the progression of the disease.
The new approach utilises a molecule already being used in clinical trials for other diseases and therefore it could move quickly into clinical development for Huntingotn's disease.
The experimental research undertaken by Simonetta Sipone produce dramatic changes with treatment leading to a complete restoration of motor skills
Patients with HD appear to have slightly lower levels of a brain molecule known as GM1. When U of A medical researchers restored GM1 to normal levels in lab models with the disease, motor skills in the lab models returned to normal within days
Sipione, team's research has been published in this weeks Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
During the research stage, lab models at the U of A were given the GM1 molecule therapy for four weeks. During the first two weeks after the treatment finished, the lab models still had normal motor function. But after that, motor function started to decline and return to pre-treatment levels by the end of the fourth week. So a potential treatment with this molecule would involve repeated treatments over the long-term, says Sipione.
Source: Ganglioside GM1 induces phosphorylation of mutant huntingtin and restores normal motor behavior in Huntington disease mice PNAS 2012 ; published ahead of print February 13, 2012, doi:10.1073/pnas.1114502109

item.title: Marina Biotech Closes Research Facility
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Marina Biotech, Inc. formerly known as MDRNA Inc, a leading nucleic acid-based drug discovery and development company has announced the closure of its Cambridge site and the consolidation of all R&D efforts at its headquarters in Bothell, WA. Meanwhile, dosing has been initiated in Cohort 2 of the START-FAP trial with CEQ508 (Safety and Tolerability of An RNAi Therapeutic in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis).
This consolidation will not impact the development of the tkRNAi platform which will continue in the labs in Bothell.
The closing of the Cambridge site was consistent with the group's continued efforts to reduce its cash utilization.
About Marina Biotech
Marina Biotech is a biotechnology company focused on the development and commercialization of oligonucleotide-based therapeutics utilizing multiple mechanisms of action including RNA interference (RNAi) and messenger RNA translational blocking.
The Marina Biotech pipeline currently includes a clinical program in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (a precancerous syndrome) and two preclinical programs in bladder cancer and malignant ascites. Marina Biotech entered into an exclusive agreement with The Debiopharm Group for the development and commercialization of the bladder cancer program (see Oncology7743: Marina Biotech Highlights Bladder Cancer R&D Collaboration & Competitive Positioning).
In addition, Marina Biotech has recently entered into an agreement with Mirna Therapeutics to license Marina Biotech's SMARTICLES® technology for the delivery of Mirna Therapeutics' microRNA mimics.

item.title: SOFT Intelligence On Abiraterone, Firmagon, Jevtana & GnRH Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:
Jevtana
Tombal seems quite happy with the efficacy he sees with Jevtana (response in 4 out of 5 patients whereas abiraterone provides response in 3 out of 10 according to him), but that safety profile is not very good for fragile patients. Indicated that price was also an issue, and Sanofi was reimbursing treatment cost to non responders. Non response is seen after 3 "cures".
Overall Market Assessment
Tombal believes the GnRH analog market will decrease in size because of the new hormonal therapy, and in particular oral options. He mentionned that bicalutamide 150mg was now given to 20% of patients in Belgium (a little above what we have seen in the EU market research of 2010). He quoted his phase I/II with MVD3100 and mentioned that the drug did not have the safety profile of the old anti-androgens, and that this was a problem, despite the fact that its affinity with the receptor was higher. He believes that the dose for hormone-naive should be less than for CRPC patients but that dose escalation by patient type has never been done.

item.title: re: Development of a Novel In Vitro Alternative to the Mouse LD50 Test
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Although the proof-of-concept aims to test for BoNT/B, modification of the assay may provide the means of detecting additional relevant BoNT types, especially BoNT/A . 
The limitations of this type of assay are:
  • Will assess receptor binding only. It would be useful in affinity studies and scatchard plot analyses.
  • Assay will not assess internalization process.
  • Assay will not assess enzymatic activity.
It may be useful in research or screening of new toxins but will require assessment of the other functional attributes of toxin required for activity.
This will have little utility in the replacement of a regulatory method for potency assessment, at least in the United States.
Steve Scott (VP Regulatory Affairs/US)

item.title: Germany's MoH Confirms Price Freeze and Mandatory Rebate
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Germany's Federal Ministry of Health (MoH) on 2 February reaffirmed the need to maintain the three-year price freeze and mandatory rebate in place since August 2010 in the country. The two emergency measures introduced 18 months ago are still justified to ensure the financial stability of the statutory health insurance, said the MoH.
Significance
Pharmaceutical prices will remain capped at their August 2009 level until at least 2013.
Meanwhile, manufacturers of non-reference-priced medicines remain obliged to pay a 16% mandatory rebate on the price of their medicine. The confirmation is bad news for the pharma industry, which faces a tough time in this former market-access haven.
As part of the new Act for the Restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Market in Statutory Health Insurance (AMNOG) pricing reform, producers of innovative medicines now have the obligation to negotiate prices in addition to paying significant rebates.
Source: Global Insight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Development of a Novel In Vitro Alternative to the Mouse LD50 Test
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The 3R Research Foundation Switzerland, a cooperative institution set up in 1987, has announced that they will provide funding for a project on the development of a novel in vitro method for use in the potency testing of botulinum neurotoxin. The new method is based on the use of liposomes with integrated nerve cell receptors to imitate the motoneuron membrane.
Although the proof-of-concept aims to test for BoNT/B, modification of the assay may provide the means of detecting additional relevant BoNT types, especially BoNT/A .
The limitations of this type of assay are:
  • Will assess receptor binding only. It would be useful in affinity studies and scatchard plot analyses.
  • Assay will not assess internalization process.
  • Assay will not assess enzymatic activity.
It may be useful in research or screening of new toxins but will require assessment of the other functional attributes of toxin required for activity.
This will have little utility in the replacement of a regulatory method for potency assessment, at least in the United States.
Steve Scott (VP Regulatory Affairs/US)
Please see @ tp://www.forschung3r.ch/en/projects/pr_125_11.html
Five research groups, from Switzerland and Germany, are involved in the collaborative project :
  • Laboratory of Food Microbiology, Institute for Food, Nutrition and Health (IFNH), ETH Zurich, Schmelzbergstrasse 7, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
  • Toxinology Group, SPIEZ LABORATORY, 3700 Spiez, Switzerland
  • Institut für Toxikologie, OE 5340, Medizinische Hochschule Hannover, Carl-Neuberg-Strasse 1, 30625 Hannover, Germany
  • miprolab GmbH, Marie-Curie-Str. 7, 37079 Göttingen, Germany
  • Federal Institute of Technology, Department of Materials, Wolfgang-Pauli-Strasse 10, 8093 Zürich, Switzerland
Objectives
  • to promote alternative research methods to animal experimentation through grants for research projects
  • to support projects aimed at developing new methods or refining accepted methods (validation) which offer practical improvements vis-à-vis standard animal experimentation in line with the 3R motto Reduce, Refine, Replace.
The 3R Foundation is set up by :
  • the Parliamentary Group for Animal Experimentation Questions (public organ),
  • Interpharma (Actelion Ltd, Merck Serono Ltd, Novartis Pharma Ltd, F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd, and the associated members Bayer Schering Pharma Switzerland, Cilag Ltd and Vifor Ltd)
  • the Foundation for Animalfree Research (animal protection).

item.title: re: Amgen Not Guaranteed Success At Tomorrow's ODAC Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Amgen Not Guaranteed Success At Tomorrow's ODAC Meeting 
Comment: Documents release ahead of tomorrow's ODAC meeting suggest that Amgen's denosumab (Xgeva) may well not receive approval to prevent the spread of bone metastases in prostate cancer patients.  ...
Much as anticipated Amgen did not get the go-ahead for approval of Xgeva to reduce the risk of developing bone metastases in CRPC patients.

At the meeting, panelists considered the evidence that patients taking Xgeva experienced a four-month delay in the spread of cancer to the bones as statistically beneficial but not a benefit that resulted in increased survival or higher quality of life for patients. It the magnitude of the benefit had been more like one year then approval may have been forthcoming but at 4 months it was considered quite low.

Panel members also expressed concern about the drug’s safety profile, including osteonecrosis of the jaw in about 5 percent of the 1432 patients studied. In addition, staff questioned whether the drug may "shift the pattern of metastases to non-bony areas."

Overall the panel believed that the drug’s risk make it safer for patients to continue only taking Xgeva when tumours already have spread to their bones.

Amgen said that it would continue discussions with the FDA regarding its filing.

item.title: Takeda Shanghai Development Center Established to Drive Growth
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Within Asia (outside Japan, including China), drug development is overseen by Takeda Global Research & Development Center (Asia) Pte. Ltd. in Singapore (“TGRD (Asia)”) and Millennium Pharm. in Cambridge (“Millennium”). The Shanghai Development Center (TSDC) will work on extending and enhancing the company’s clinical development activities within the Asian region, with a focus on China for General Medicine working as an integrated regional team with TGRD (Asia), and across Asia for Oncology.
- Through the resources of TSDC, Takeda will continue to conduct high quality clinical trials which will lead to secure regulatory approval in Asia, with a growing emphasis on China, and continue to build deeper relationships with physicians and regulatory authorities.
- The acquisition of Nycomed has immediately established the company in high-growth emerging markets. The establishment of TSDC will help the company leveraging its activities.

item.title: Exelixis Results Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: M. Morrissey (President & CEO) reported that 2 planned pivotal trial programs (COMET1 and COMET2) in mCRPC will drive cabozantinib differentiation in CRPC. While Management focus is internal efforts in the CRPC space, it continues to implement its plans to maximize the drug's potential in additional tumour indications through external collaborations. Nine abstracts on cabozantinib will be presented at the upcoming ASCO in June.
COMET1 (307 study)
  • Start date: H1 2012
  • Location: Up to 200 on a WW basis
  • Top line results expected H1 2014.
COMET2 (306 study) - pain palliation study
  • Start date: first site initiated in Dec. 2011 (see Oncology8049: New Cabozantinib Study to Assess Pain Associated with Metastases in Men with CRPC)
  • Location: up to 40 sites
Differentiated Thyroid Cancer (DTC) - the company had a pre-NDA meeting in 2011 and obtained agreement from the FDA to initiate a rolling NDA. Filling is on track to complete H1 2012.
Renal Cell Carcinoma
Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)
Metastatic Breast Cancer (MBC)
  • Restructuring activities are complete
  • All non-cabozantinib development activities discontinued.
  • Of note, Exelixis started 2012 with over $300M in cash.
  • Out-licensing of PI3K delta program to Merck (see Oncology7980: Licensing of Exelixis' PI3K-delta Program to Provide Resources for Late-Stage Dev. of Cabozantinib).

item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Morgan Stanley is expecting Allergan to communicate a strong pipeline poistion at its March 28th analyst day. During his meeting with the analysts, Pyott stated his belief that the top three most exciting pipeline candidates are Latisse for hair loss, targeted Botox for pain and DARPinn for Wet AMD.
The analysts are suggesting that Allergan could initiate phIII trials with the targeted toxin for pain this year but may also be unveilling of some surprise new development candidates.
Key ongoing developments with the three most promising candidates potentially explains the higher than expected expansion in R&D spending noted during the 2nd February call.
The analysts published their note with a raised price target of $98 based on an extension of their model to 2020. Some of the key assumptions behind this price target are shown below.

item.title: GSK Results Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: GSK reported an improving sales picture in underlying terms +4%, underpinned by strong growth of new products. It also painted a picture of increasing returns on R&D and pipeline progress. Comprehensive phIII data on its GLP-1 analogue albiglutide is likely to be presented at a forthcoming R&D day to be announced around the time of the Q1 results.
Drugs In Development - Key Comments
Albiglutide
Patrick Vallance SVP-Medicines Discovery & Development, noted that some of the phIII data is available but that there's more coming in.He stated "So where we are with this is it's a product that didn't meet the once-a-day efficacy in the first bit, but actually very well tolerated. We expect that efficacy to continue. We're very optimistic, actually, that this is a nice product with a very good tolerability profile that will have a good place in the market."
Votrient (multi-kinase inhibitor pazopanib)
Votrient has achieved an 18% total prescription share in the US advanced renal cell carcinoma market. Head-to-head data in 2012 from an event-driven study comparing Votrient to the current market leader, Sutent (which has a market share of approximately 50%) is expected in 2012. Votrient is also under regulatory review in the USA and Europe for a new indication in soft-tissue sarcoma and in phIII development for renal cancer.
A number of phII ESS studies remain ongoing with pazopanib evaluating its use in the treatment of neuroendocrine tumours and pNET
Two other notable products in phase III development are for Crohn's disease and GSK2402968 for Duchene's Musucular Dystrophy
Source: www.gsk.com

item.title: New Prostate Drug Target Identified
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The February 6th publication of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences highlights a new target for potential prostate cancer therapy intervention, a protein called ARD1.
Wango Lui Associated Professor of Genetics at LSU Health Sciences Centre New Orleans has identified what is claimed to be a new protein critical to the development of prostate cancer.
Dr Lui's team have been studying androgen receptor activators and discovered that this new protein ARD1 is overproduced in the majority of prostate cancer samples, that it activates the the androgen receptor and that it is an essential component of prostate cancer cell growth.
Moreoever, it seems that inactivation of ARD1 inhibits the function of the androgen receptor resulting in complete suppression of prostate cancer cell growth in tissue culture and prostate tumour growth in mice.
Dr Lui claims that his team's study provides a novel avenue for controlling AR-mediated prostate tumour development by directly inhibiting the function of the ARD1 or AR-ARD1 interaction.
http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2012/02/01/1113356109.abstract

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Amgen Not Guaranteed Success At Tomorrow's ODAC Meeting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Documents release ahead of tomorrow's ODAC meeting suggest that Amgen's denosumab (Xgeva) may well not receive approval to prevent the spread of bone metastases in prostate cancer patients.
What is the issue?
Whilst Amgen's study that examined how Xgeva might reduce the risk of developing bone metasteses in patients with CRPC and high risk factors met its pre-specified primary endpoint, it is unclear whether an improvement in median bone metastasis-free survival by 4.2 months is an adequate measure of clinical benefit.
The FDA's pre-meeting report is critical of the use of this endpoint. Moreove, analysts are suggesting that the oncology as opposed to urology profile of the committee members does not help Amgen's case as it is their preference to see new prostate cancer drugs demonstrating an improvement in overall survival.

Comments
Much as anticipated Amgen did not get the go-ahead for approval of Xgeva to reduce the risk of developing bone metastases in CRPC patients.

At the meeting, panelists considered the evidence that patients taking Xgeva experienced a four-month delay in the spread of cancer to the bones as statistically beneficial but not a benefit that resulted in increased survival or higher quality of life for patients. It the magnitude of the benefit had been more like one year then approval may have been forthcoming but at 4 months it was considered quite low.

Panel members also expressed concern about the drug’s safety profile, including osteonecrosis of the jaw in about 5 percent of the 1432 patients studied. In addition, staff questioned whether the drug may "shift the pattern of metastases to non-bony areas."

Overall the panel believed that the drug’s risk make it safer for patients to continue only taking Xgeva when tumours already have spread to their bones.

Amgen said that it would continue discussions with the FDA regarding its filing.


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Europe: eTACT Anti-Counterfeit System
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The eTACT traceability system for medicines has been officially launched by the European Directorate for the Quality of Medicines and Healthcare ( EDQM), part of the Council of Europe.

eTACT will be a publicly governed service covering all medicines in the legal supply chain, and will be open to the 36 member states of the European Pharmacopoeia Commission and beyond.

However, a mixed pharmaceutical industry/distributor grouping has already tested another scheme, the European Stakeholder Model (ESM). Its proponents also claim their system will be a "practical and cost-effective solution" to the growing problem of falsified medicines.

It is not clear which of the two systems will eventually predominate, or whether the end result will be some sort of combination of the two, as there may be collaboration between the two systems.

Source: Scrip 6 February 2012


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Norgine Reports Ph2 Results of a New Orange Flavoured Formulation of MOVIPREP®
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The results have shown that MOVIPREP® Orange was well tolerated. In addition, a high rating of successful cleansing (96%) similar to rates shown by MOVIPREP® Lemon (the parent product) was observed.
Primary endpoint: Overall Acceptance on VAS (100mm) rating
Recruitment: 121 subjects were enrolled, of which 118 were eligible to be randomised.
Location: 5 specialised gastroenterology units in private practice or ambulatory care centres in Germany.
Dosage: 1 litre of MOVIPREP® Orange in the evening ahead of the colonoscopy and 1 litre early in the morning on the day of the colonoscopy. Each dose of MOVIPREP® Orange was followed by at least 0.5 litre of any additional clear fluid.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Medivations's Review Of the AFFIRM Trial & The Future CRPC Treatment Paradigm
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: During last week's call on the MDV3100 results several interesting points emerged regarding the furture treatment paradigm in CRPC (usage ahead of abiraterone), potential ways to treat non-responders and potentially the use of AR modulators for the treatment of breast cancer.
Invited speakers on the call were:-
Howard I. Scher, MD Chief, Genitourinary Oncology Service; D. Wayne Calloway Chair in Urologic Oncology, Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Neal D. Shore, M.D., FACS Director, CPI, Carolina Urologic Research Center
In the Q/A session the following points were addressed:-
How is MDV3100 likely to be positioned in oncology as well as urology and relative to PROVENGE by 2015.
Howard Scher:- "So the way essentially that most of us practice now for the patient who requires hormonal treatment, we generally begin with a GnRH analogue or whether it's an agonist antagonist or pure antagonist. Some will still use an antiandrogen for a short period of time, but that data I think has been beat to death over time and really does not change outcomes to a significant degree. When the patient has progressed, we will typically – if they are progressing slowly than add an anti-androgen which has a very modest response rate, and then we will move on to – in the past we moved on to the steroid containing adrenal access, originally called adrenal access agents such as ketoconazole. I think if we wind the clock ahead a few years that paradigm will have not changed except the anti-androgen will be replaced by a new generation compound of androgen receptor signaling inhibitor.
"I am not sure when PREVAIL will be out, but anticipating what we saw in the Phase 1, 2 study that will be positioned first, that will be based on safety and the fact that you don't need steroids, which is a way that communities have been practicing really for the past 20, 30 years. If you want me to wind the clock even further forward, there is a potential role for this agent in the non-castrate population. And those trials have actually been started in Europe, which really offers an enormous number of additional possibilities."
"The issue with Provenge is very simple and it does have a Phase 3 survival trial, but it's challenging when you actually use it, because you can't assess whether it has benefited a single individual patient. Its availability has been limited. Its cost is not inconsequential and it's rarily been used. The patient response to it is highly variable. Some will want everything done, some will say, I want to know if it works, but it's really been primarily used, at least as I've seen it in patients who have relatively indolent disease who have no symptoms, who have not seen steroids or have not seen chemotherapy. So I think it's really hard to prescribe it, I mean, discuss it. But it's not clear again for the individual patient what it actually does. I know Neal you have more experience with it than I do."
Neal Shore:- "Well, I think you asked really the $64 question is all about combinations and sequencing. I think I agree with everything that Howard said and he gave you a very terse and cogent answer to a very difficult question. But I think as it relates to the Medivation drug MDV3100, I don't see there being any exclusionary therapies that would prevent concomitant therapy with MDV3100 based upon its mechanism of action, its once-a-day oral administration and its safety profile. Of course, the big caveat is, we have to do those trials. Those trials have to be done and that's what we have to work on Level 1 evidence, but having said that, to fast forward to 2015, my presumption is that there is nothing going to be exclusionary to MDV3100."
Q Combination Therapy - What kind of synergy do you have to observe to actually make that strong Level 1 evidence, considering the costs and everything?
Howard Scher:- "I think the real question you are asking is, what signal would you want when you did an initial combinatorial study to make the investment to do a very large Phase 3 trial. That you know again there is no regulatory endpoint. Right now sort of survival with one exception and that has been skeletal-related events, which are very infrequent in the asymptomatic population and that would be an enormous cause. And I'm not sure there is a clear signal right now, we've extrapolated to a degree based on the time to progression measures, but those have not themselves been approvable. It's not clear that you would see an increase in response rate by combining the two. So it was likely we stuck with us to see whether a biologic could prolong the response. So it's obviously scientifically very interesting, particularly with this safety profile, but from a drug development standpoint it would be very challenging at this point in time."
Q How do you believe Zytgia and MDV3100 should be sequenced in the post chemo setting?
Howard Scher:-"The steroid issue is non-trivial. This causes skin changes, it causes muscle weakness and that's really the start, it's kind of an agent that does not require steroids, particularly long term in my view is going to be utilized first and that's the way the community has been practicing in the prechemotherapy space literally for the past 30 years when the anti-androgens were first approved. I don't see this changing in the post-chemotherapy setting. Couple that with the ease of administration, I think it just reinforces which one you would use first. So the real question is, are these drugs the same and probably ask that every day, what would they look like in combination? And, as Neal mentioned, these are trials that have to be done. But right now, given the choice, we would use a non-steroid-containing regimen first."
Neil Shore:-"Yeah, I would agree with that. The safety profile, the ease of acceptance and the lack of monitoring presumably with the label based upon the safety and tolerability data that you're seeing presented today would certainly make it a more enjoyable and an ease-of-use product for the patient, first and foremost and also for the clinician in the community, there is no doubt about that."
Q Any potential limitations to use in the chemo-naive patient setting?
Howard Scher:-"We really haven't seen any limitation in the pre-chemotherapy population in our own experience that precludes long-term use".
Q Over the coming months and maybe years might we be able to stratify or identify patients more likely to respond to this drug or less likely to exhibit resistance than we are currently able to do?
Howard Scher:- So that's certainly a major goal of the investigations now. There is clearly a small cohort with both Abiraterone and with MDV3100, who primarily are non-responsive to these agents. In laboratory models there have been several, so to say, first-order targets, which are being investigated.
"We know that the PTEN pathway negatively inhibits when there is activated AR signaling. And I think that's a strategy that the prostate cancer research community is aggressively looking at with multiple different agents both with the androgen receptor signaling inhibitors as well as with abiraterone. And as you know there are a number of agents targeting virtually every aspect of the PI3-Kinase pathway. Key is going to be having a strong enough hypothesis to test.
"The second requirement is going to be the development of the assays, which will be necessary in order to do this type of prediction. The rules at the FDA level have changed now. So in the old days, if you will, it was sufficient to do an assay in a research setting, that's no longer the case and any assay that you wish to use in the clinic in order to inform a decision to select drug A versus drug B will have to go through its own regulatory filing. So right now what we're focusing on in our group is developing the analytical rigor, so we can do the filings and then begin the trials to actually ask the question. But it's clearly where the field is heading."
Q: Rational for MDV3100 working in breast cancer?
David Hung CEO of Medivation - " So there is a fairly good evidence and a fairly bundled literature showing that AR is expressed, not only in ER positive breast cancer, but also ER negative breast cancer. And so we've done a number of preclinical experiments, both internally as well as with some collaborators, including Jennifer Richer from the University of Colorado at Denver showing that MDV3100 inhibits not only DHT or testosterone-mediated breast cancer growth, but interestingly, it also inhibits estradiol or estrogen-mediated breast cancer growth. So, we are very intrigued by these data. We believe this is a potentially very large commercial opportunity and given that the, what we believe, is a very sound scientific rationale we're pushing forward aggressively to try to move into a breast cancer indication as quickly as we can."

item.title: Novartis Expresses Concerns Over Spain's Drug Repayments
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Our colleagues in Spain have drawn our attention to the Novartis' warning regarding the risk of the unpaid by Greece, Italy and Spain. The latter being identified by the company as one of the most concern. According to data supplied by Farmaindustria, autonomous communities in Spain owed more 6bn to the pharma industry at the end of 2011.
The average payment-delay period has also increased over the last year by 135 days, reaching a peak of 525 days by December 2011.
Four autonomous communities—Comunidad Valenciana, Baleares, Castilla y Leon, and Cantabria—exceeded this average, reaching over 800 days in payment delays.
The new Spanish government needs to act quickly in order to deal with the problem of payment delays, or runs the risk of a ban on product sales from some of the largest pharma companies until debts are repaid.
Sources: Novartis' AR; Global Insight; Europa Press

item.title: Astellas Announces Reorganization of its Global Management Structure
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The reorganization will be effective from April 1st. The Global Medical Affairs (GMA) and the Global Marketing Strategy (GMS) organizations will be newly established, as well as the positions of Corporate Executives, responsible for Corporate Strategy and Finance. Details and objectives are provided below.
  • Newly established positions of Corporate Executives Responsible for Corporate Strategy and Finance, reporting Directly to the President.
  • Newly Establish Global Medical Affairs Structure and Global Marketing Strategy Structure
GMA Overview
GMA develops medical strategy and supports the execution of global medical strategy in partnership with stakeholders and in collaboration with regions to optimize medical/scientific value across the product lifecycle.
Medical and scientific evaluation in the key therapeutic area of urology, oncology, transplantation, immunology and infectious diseases through the promotion of organic collaboration between various functions from the development stage onwards across various regions ・
Function Head: Charlotte M. E. Kremer, MD (Appointed January 9, 2012)
GMS Overview
Global product market launch strategy (Pre-market launch branding strategy, therapeutic area strategy, market launch planning), and post-market launch lifecycle plan creation
Create positions of Therapeutic Area Head for the promotion of collaboration with the APGD and GMA in the key therapeutic area of urology, oncology, transplantation, immunology and infectious diseases
Function Head: VP, Product and Portfolio Strategy

item.title: Assay Using Neurons from Stem Cells for Botulinum Toxin Detection
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:: A team from the University of Wisconsin-Madison have published data in the Toxicological science journal on a test they have developed employing stem cell derivatives to reliably and quantitatively detect botulinum neurotoxin and the antibodies that can neutralize the toxin's effects. Data on this assay was first presented at the Toxins meeting in Santa Fe in October 2011 (see Neurology6028: Toxins Intelligence Part 1 - New Botulinum Toxin Assays).
The assay is more sensitive than the mouse assay.
Sabine Pellett of University of Wisconsin-Madison said that the assay the team has developed is another cell based assay, one that uses normal human neurons derived from induced pluripotent stem cells, and which can be optimized for any pharmaceutical botulinum neurotoxin product.
Source: Toxicological Sciences journal.
Abstract at: http://toxsci.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/01/19/toxsci.kfr354.abstract?sid=35037e51-a846-4c57-9dd0-c46d35ea7399

item.title: Asia Key Country for Allergan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an interview with Reuters, Management has reported that Allergan will rely less on the U.S for revenues in coming year, as its products gain wider acceptance in Asia, with China to be the main driver.
Ian Bell (Corporate VP and President for Asia Pacific) told Reuters that cosmetic clinics in big hospitals in major Chinese cities present an opportunity for Allergan's aesthetic products.
He outlined that Juvederm is expected to reach the Chinese market in 2014-2015.

Comments
Allergan has currently authorised 180 Chinese hospitals nationwide to use Botox, including the major facilities of Shanghai Huamei Aesthetic in Shanghai and the Zhuhai Luda Plastic Surgery Hospital in Guangdong province.
Ian Bell said that Allergan has deliberately focused on physician training, working in partnership with select hospitals in key cities in China, instead of making it available everywhere in China.
He added that a local production plant in China is not planned because Allergan's existing facilities can meet global demand.
Source: Scrip 20 February 2012

item.title: Oncogenex @ ASCO GI - OGX-427 Prostate Cancer Data
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company has provided an initial read on its Ph2 study of OGX-427 + prednisone for 1st-line mCRPC. Preliminary data provide clinical support for the role of Hsp27 in AR signalling and as a therapeutic target for prostate cancer. Enrolment on this study continues, with final results expected to be announced by the end of 2012.
Study Design - NCT01120470
Results
OGX-427 appeared to benefit patients most notably by a 71% progression-free rate in the OGX-427 + prednisone group (n=17) compared to 33% in the prednisone alone group (n=15).
There was a partial response rate (measured at 12 weeks) of 38% (n=8) in the OGX-427 + prednisone group compared to 0% in the prednisone group (n=9).
The rate of adverse events (AEs), particularly withdrawal from the study due to AEs, was higher in the OGX-427 + prednisone group.
Next Steps
Randomized ph2 study of OGX-427 in combination with Zytiga (to start H2 2012).

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: European Botox Sales Under Some Pressure
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan recorded a 6.4% increase in net earnings in the fourth quarter as higher sales of opthalmics offset what analysts considered lower than expected sales of Botox ($415m vs estimates of around $430m for Q4).
Global Botox Sales
Specifically sales of Botox increased by 8.3% in the fourth quarter in local currencies and by 7.5% in dollars. Full year 2011 sales grew by 10.4% in local currencies, and 12.4% in dollars. Sales of Botox for therapeutic indications and cosmetic use, both grew 12% versus the prior year.
Therapeutic Botox Developments
Sales in the U.S. therapeutic business grew at a mid teens rate in Q4 driven not only by chronic migraine which is increasing steadily well in excess of this rate but also boosted by the nuerogenic overactive bladder indication (launched in the US in November)
Pyott noted that the U.S. chronic migraine launch is progressing very well and better than planned with 4600 individual physicians now trained either via the web or live injector training sessions. The reimbursement situation also continues to improve with 88% of all commercial coverage at year end. As physicians become convinced that there is reimbursement available, the average number of units injected moves closer to the FDA indicated dose of 155 units.
To support uptake Allergan has been running a DTC campaign since September but from this month onwards it will be placing branded advertisements in women's magazines.
It claims that its surveys are indicating a high level of patient satisfaction.
Additional country approvals for chronic migraine in the past quarter have included Canada, Sweden, Spain, Vietnam, Bangladesh and Peru. On the approval front the company also noted that it has received a positive opinion in France for its new cell based Botox assay and approval in the Czech republic.
Regarding US competition, Allergan is reporting that in the therapeutic segment the combined impact of Xeomin and Dysport is stagnating around 5%.
Pyott did note that its therapeutic sales in Europe have suffered from government posterity measures as well as the impact of mandated price reductions but that sales in Asia Pacific markets and the largest countries in Latin America, continue to grow at a double digit rate. Sales from its partner GLaxosmithkline in Japan have also been on a strong growth trend.
Aesthetic Botox Growth
Pyott noted that U.S. market conditions remain good and appear to have strengthened since the summer. Consumer demand for Botox he suggests grew in the low double digits in Q4 and competitors market share he reports as 17% for Dysport and 8% for Xeomin. In the Q& A he claimed to be surprised by Xeomin's share but then registerd that most of that has been obtained through sampling. He suggests it will be a different matter when they have national availability in March and have to start selling the product. Then he claims "it will become more interesting and we will have a very robust series of measures to welcome them to our nice friendly market"

Sales in Europe, meanwhile, have reportedly been more challenging due to economic conditions and some market share loss has occurred as Boucature (Merz) and Azzalure (Galderma) have entered new markets.
Asia-Pacific growth remains firm and Allergan was pleased to note that it has established a direct sales presence in Russia as of this week.
Urological Uptake
Pyotts remarks about this segment were as follows:-
"It has been almost a normal launch pattern where the first goal is getting injectors trained. The second one is getting reimbursement in place. And right now, there's only temporary injection codes being utilized so that's always more challenging. We won't get a permanent code until 2013 because it takes a year until the system catches up."
"So everything's going well. There's a lot of enthusiasm but of course we'll have to kind of temper everybody's enthusiasm by saying the numbers are interesting but in 2012 still modest. You'll see a much bigger pickup in 2013. Once reimbursement is permanent. And secondly once we the bigger idiopathic indication is approved.
Botox Forecast
Allergan is expecting double-digit sales growth in 2012 led by newly approved therapeutic indications.
Some disappointment was expressed by analysts in the rate of therapeutic versus aesthetic growth. Pyott reassured noting that the therapeutic launches are a very long ramp but that a take-off is expected in 2012. This should be underpinned in 2013 by the launch of the idiopathic overactive bladder indication.
Development plans were not discussed in detail during today's call but will be highlighted in more detail at the group's R&D investor day in late March
Source: www.allergan.com

item.title: New Ph3 Study with Novartis' Everolimus for NETs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis is to start the Radiant-4 study in March 2012, to compare the antitumor activity of everolimus plus best supportive care (BSC) vs. placebo plus BSC in patients with advanced non-functional NET of GI or lung origin. Primary endpoint will assess time to PFS.
Everolimus might be more beneficial against advanced NETs than previously recognized.
http://connection.asco.org/forums/forumid/22/postid/442/scope/posts.aspx#442
Recruitment: approx. 279
The study is to complete in November 2017.
Dosage: everolimus 10mg once daily until disease progression, intolerable toxicity, or consent withdrawal.
Location: U.S

item.title: Novo Nordisk 2011 Results - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: NovoNordisk has lifted its sales outlook after reporting a strong increase in 2011 sales +11% in local curerncies and a 22% increase in operating profits (+18% in DKK). The star performer has been and is expected to be the GLP-1 analogue Victoza sales of which grew by 159% to DKK5.9bn. Development progress with the hemophilia pipeline was also reported.
Victoza Roll-Out
The global roll-out is continuing, now with 48 countries having launched Victoza®, most recently Oman, Thailand, Bulgaria, Belarus, Taiwan and Jordan.
Victoza® has achieved global market share leadership with 58% value market share in the GLP-1 segment in November 2011 compared to 30% in November 2010. Moreover, the GLP-1 class‟s value share of the total diabetes care market increased to 4.5% in November 2011 compared to 3.2% in November 2010.
Victoza® was launched in China during the fourth quarter of 2011, and although initial market feedback has reportedly been positive, actual sales are so far limited.
Japan & Korea Sales in Japan & Korea increased, from a relatively low base in 2010, by 348% in local currencies and by 370% measured in Danish kroner in 2011.
Hemophilia Franchise
Sales of NovoSeven® increased by 7% in local currencies and by 4% in Danish kroner to DKK 8,347 million compared to 2010. All regions contributed to the sales growth although International Operations was the primary contributor to growth followed by Europe and North America.
Key Developments
Turoctocog alfa, a recombinant FVIII, has completed its phase 3a programme. the largest registration trial ever conducted for a factor VIII product.
Turoctocog alfa has been dosed to 150 haemophilia A patients with 75 exposures each. The safety profile was reportedly positive with no patients developing an inhibitor and only few adverse events reported. A high success rate was observed in both treatment of bleeds and in reduction of number of bleeds. Turoctocog alfa also demonstrated a 100% success rate in preventing bleeds during surgery in both children and adults. Equally positive results were observed in a paediatric trial of turoctocog alfa including 63 children below 12 years of age. No inhibitory antibodies were reported in children, and a high efficacy in both treatment and prevention of bleeds was observed.
Based on these results, Novo Nordisk will work towards submission to regulatory authorities during the second half of 2012.
Meanwhile, regarding Recombinant FXIII, the company has received a Complete Response Letter in the US from the FDA regarding its application to market the drug for congenital factor XIII deficiency noting that the agency will require additional information prior to considering the product for approval.
Growth Hormone Performance & Development
Sales of Norditropin® increased by 5% measured in local currencies and by 5% measured in Danish kroner to DKK 5,047 million compared to 2010. The sales growth was driven by International Operations, North America and Japan & Korea, partly offset by a decline in Europe. Novo Nordisk remains the second-largest supplier in the global growth hormone market with a 24% share measured in volume. After previous setbacks with a long-acting growth hormone, NovoNordisk has announced the initiation of a phI trial with a new long-acting formulation NN8640, The aim of the trial is to investigate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of the compound in healthy male subjects.
Group Outlook

item.title: AstraZeneca 2011 Results - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Competition from generics and price cuts had a negative impact on the sales, which were down 2% to $ 33.591bn. 2012 guidance is for a low double-digit decline in revenues. The group expects another $1.6B of annual savings from third restructuring in 5 years. The total number of positions expected to be impacted for this phase is estimated to be approx. 7,300. Of note the new R&D orientation in neurosciences.
A focus for much of the change in R&D is the neuroscience therapy area. As a result, AstraZeneca will create a new “virtual” neuroscience Innovative Medicines unit (iMed) made up of a small team of around 40 to 50 AstraZeneca scientists conducting discovery and development externally, through a network of some of the most innovative partners in academia and industry globally. The team will be based in major neuroscience hubs – Boston (US) and Cambridge (UK) – and work closely with innovative partners such as the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm (Sweden).

item.title: Switzerland Becomes the First EU Country to Approve Allergan's Non-Animal Test
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: SwissMedic has approved Allergan’s fully in vitro, cell-based assay for use in the stability and potency testing of BOTOX® and VISTABEL®.
Allergan has disclosed it plans to work with the European medicines regulators so that this non-animal assay can be used for the commercial batch release of BOTOX® and VISTABEL® sold in Europe.
The company confirmed that it has already filed for approval throughout the EU.
Source: http://www.buav.org/article/933/the-buav-welcomes-swiss-regulators-acceptance-of-non-animal-test-for-botox

item.title: J&J's Zytiga (abiraterone) Too Expensive for National Health Service (NHS)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:
Cost Issue
Although

Comments
The All Wales Medicines Strategy Group has approved Zytiga (abiraterone acetate) for men with advanced castration resistant prostate cancer - specifically, Zytiga is indicated for use alongside with prednisone or prednisolone in adult men whose disease has progressed after a docetaxel-based chemotherapy regimen.
The AWMSG were able to approve abiraterone after assessing it as an end of life drug, meaning it will now be available on the NHS in Wales until NICE release their final guidance, which will override the AWMSG decision if abiraterone is rejected.
http://www.wales.nhs.uk/sites3/Documents/371/Abiraterone%20%28Zytiga%29%20FAR.pdf
Source Pharmatimes 20 February 2012/AWMSG

item.title: Takeda Q32011 - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda registered strong third quarter revenue growth primarily due to the acquisition of Nycomed but operating profit/margins and net income fell substantially. Numbers aside the focus of its presentation was on the re-organisation of its R&D and the competitive positioning of TAK-700 which it believes will be the first anti-hormonal agent for CRPC to be approved in Japan.
In its webcast Takeda focused on the reorganisation of its R&D and its guiding principals.
Tadataka Yamada noted:-
"We are in a process right now structuring the R&D organization somewhat differently than in the past and at another time, I will go into greater detail on how we have structured. But for the moment, I do want to explain that the strategic product planning department of Takeda has now been amalgamated into the R&D organization and has been divided into three separate groups. One group that leads the therapeutic areas, another group called New Frontier Sciences that will explore opportunities for bringing important, early scientific platforms into the company. And then third, that will support the office function or R&D. Mr. Iwasaki who's currently the Head of the Strategic Product Planning Department will support me in the Chief Medical and Scientific Officer office."
"Now a critical element about the new R&D organization is focused on key principles that have a very narrow and pinpoint attention to patient needs. We believe that understanding the relationship with a patient will help us greatly as we try to make new products for them. One of the most important principles in this is to have a sense of urgency about what we're doing. Of course there are many patients who are suffering greatly. We understand that we can do something to relieve their suffering. And an intrinsic appreciation of this will have a great motivating factor for our scientists."
Specific Comments on TAK-700
When questioned about the competitive positioning of TAK-700 in light of the MDV3100 data Hiroshi Takahara stated:-
"TAK-700 is a 17, 20 lyase inhibitor and it preferentially inhibits the production of testosterone without the same level of impact on the production of cortisol that a drug like Abiraterone which inhibits a different axis, which includes the 17 hydroxylase enzymes. So, Abiraterone will always need to be taken with a steroid to supplement the cortisol. TAK-700 has the possibility to be taken without a steroid in earlier prostate cancer. And in the metastatic trials that we have ongoing, two Phase III global trials in prostate cancer patients whose disease has metastasized, who have either received chemotherapy and failed or have not yet received chemotherapy. In those two settings with metastatic patients, TAK-700 is used with a steroid because the steroid actually has an anti-cancer effect in and of itself. But as we move into earlier prostate cancer, we anticipate it would be used without a steroid with concomitant – avoiding the concomitant side effects of the steroid. The results with MDV3100 were very good and we anticipate that these two products, TAK-700 and MDV3100, could have similar outcomes but could also potentially be used together in that the mechanisms of hormone suppression are different and therefore may be combinable for an even greater result. We anticipate that TAK-700, while it will not be first to market outside of Japan, could still have the opportunity to be first to market in Japan and as you saw our announcement earlier, we have now included the first Japanese patients into the global Phase III trials. I hope that gives you some background to your question"
Source: takeda.com

item.title: Savient CEO to Replace Dendreon CEO
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Mitchell Gold will step down from the post, and hold that position until June 30 when Johnson will become CEO & chairman of Dendreon. Rationale for this change has been attributed to the disappointing launch of Dendreon's Provenge.
J. H. Johnson was appointed chief executive officer of Savient Pharm. in January 2011.
Prior to this appointment, he served as a senior vice president of Eli Lilly and Company and president of Lilly Oncology Business Unit, where he was responsible for multi-billion dollar franchise including a development portfolio of over 30 oncology products.
From August 2007 to November 2009, he was CEO of ImClone Systems, and served on ImClone's board of directors until the company was acquired by Lilly in November 2008.

item.title: Astellas Q2 FY2011 Results - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas has reported revenue growth of +4%, recording growth in all regions but with US sales notably up 18% due to a first time contribution from OSI and a strong performance from the TKI inhibitor Tarceva. Eligard's growth remains solid and the company's R&D pipeline looks to be moving into a productive phase with noteworthy MDV3100 data also reported today.
Sales in Europe grew by 6% with Vesidcare, Eligard and Mycamine strong contributors.
Highlighted below are what the group considers to be its major achievements during the first half including the registration filings (EU and US August 2011) for its new urology agent mirabegron for iOAB and steady progress with its prostate cancer drug MDV3100 and its renal cancer drug tivoaznib.
Key R&D Developments
Astellas continues to make good progress with its oncology pipeline having reported strong MDV3100 data today and as shown below and a survival benefit in its ph2 study with its pancreatic cancer drug AGS-1C4D4. It is also highlighting a new prostate cancer drug in its pipeline which has entered phI development.

item.title: MDV3100 Post Docetaxel Data Looks Very Promising
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Astellas and Medivation have today released the full results of the phIII AFFIRM trial ahead of the presentation at ASCO GU tomorrow. The data from this 1199 patient study is robust and highly statistically significant in terms of both primary and all secondary endpoints. It fully validates the androgen signalling pathway as mechanistically important in the CRPC setting.
In this post doceaxel setting resuts of particular note are as follows:-
  • Men taking MDV3100 lived for a median of 18,4 months compared with 13.6 months for those taking placebo (p<0.0001 HR=0.631)
  • MDV31000 also met all secondary endpoints including radiographic progression free survival *8.3 vs. 2.9 months p<0.0001 HR =0.404.
  • Soft tissue response rate 28.9% vs. 3.8% p<0.0001
  • Time to PSA progression 8.3 vs. 3.0 months p<0.0001: HR=0.249
  • PSA declines of 50% or greater were more common in the MDV3100 group than in the placebo group (54% vs. 1.5% p<0.0001
Safety Profile
MDV3100 was well tolerated. Serious AEs were lower in the MDV3100 group than in the placebo group. Comparative Grade 3 AEs of note were fatigue (6.3% in the MDV3100 group vs 7.0% in the placebo arm, cardiac disorders (0.9% vs 2.0%), seizure (0.6% vs 0.0%), LFT abnormalities 0.4% vs. 0.8%.
Commenting on the results Professor Jonathon De Bono (Royal Marsden UK), co-principal investigator for the AFFIRM trial stated "The almost 5-month survival benefit MDV3100 showed over placeob in this trial is noteworthy, as is the fact that men with post chemotherapy prostate cancer lived for a median of a year and a half.
Medivation's CEO noted that based on this robust data and together with its partner Astellas it is committed to working diligently to bring MDV3100 to the market as quickly as possible.
The data will be highlighted in a late breaking oral presentation tomorrow at the ASCO GU Meeting (see Oncology8047: Forthcoming ASCO GU Conference - Key Presentations) and will be followed by a Medivation hosted conference call to discuss the results.
For more information on the MDV3100 please refer to Astellas's last presentation in November (see Oncology7900: Highlights from Astellas' Press Conference)
www.medivation.com

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Exelixis has planned to start this month a Ph3 randomized, double-blind, controlled trial to assess the effect of cabozantinib vs. mitoxantrone plus prednisone on pain response (primary endpoint).
- COMET-2
Secondary endpoint will assess bone scan response.
Recruitment: approx. 246
Est. Primary Completion Date: June 2013.

item.title: Pfizer's 2011 Performance - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pfizer has reported a sharp fall in fourth quarter earnings as generic erosion of Lipitor starts to impact. Q4 sales were marginally better than analysts predicted down by 4% set against the backdrop of a 24% decline inLipitor sales. However, of interest was that Somavert (pegvisoment) and Sutent were amongst the group's 6 fastest growing products.
Somavert Sales
Whilst still small in absolute terms relative to group revenues of $67.4bn, global Somavert revenues of $183 were up 17% with growth in the fourth quarter +19%. Geographically, the biggest contributor to growth is ex-US notably Europe where sales grew from $109m in 2010 to $121m in 2011 (+6% ex currency).
Sutent Sales
Sutent Pfizer's multikinase inhibitor which received an expanded label in 2011 to include pNET on top of previous approvals for renal carcinoma and GIST generated sales of $1.18bn +11% (l.c. +8%). Q4 sales were up 7% to 317 with the fastest growth occuring in the US.
Genotropin
W/W sales were flat in 2011 but down in local currencies -4%. Sales have declined in most markets with the exception of the Developed ROW which includes Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, and South Korea where growth was +18%. In a bid to rejuvinate growth and capture market share from the biosimilars, Pfizer has taken the first steps in some markets to reduce its price level to that of Omnitrope.
Source: pfizer.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Italy: Price War Between Generics and Originators ?
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: A new law introducing stricter prescribing restrictions in Italy could save up to €1 billion and lead to a price war says AssoGenerici, the Italian generic medicines association. However, the new law is still to pass through parliament.
Generic medicines have traditionally had a low market share in Italy and currently take 16% of the volume market. The new law aims to ensure that cheaper medicines, if available, are actually dispensed. In 90% of cases these medicines would be generics.
Recently, generics manufacturers have faced fierce competition from originators. This is because originators have been lowering their prices to near generic levels in a bid to maintain their market share.
The R&D-based industry claims that the new law will worsen market conditions, driving manufacturing abroad and forcing further plant closures.
See also PharmaWorld9761: P&R End-of-Year Review 2011 and Outlook for 2012
Source: Scrip 31 Janaury 2012

item.title: Molecular Insights ' Radiopharmaceutical to Enter Clinical for Targeted Treatment of mPC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The company anticipates to start Ph1 in early 2013 with I-131-MIP-1466, a radiopharmaceutical radiolabeled with I-131 to enable targeted radiotherapy.
- MOA: systemic radiotherapy designed to deliver a therapeutic dose of radiation directly to metastatic prostate cancer
- PC Results: the drug inhibits tumour growth in human prostate cancer xenografts
- MSO: Centre for Probe Development and Commercialization (CPDC, Hamilton, ON). The Centre has introduced several new radiopharmaceuticals to Ontario that are now being used in clinical trials to diagnose and stage various cancers and to monitor patient response in chemotherapy trials.
Source: Molecular Insight PR

item.title: New Botox Study Targets Knee Pain
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan has initiated a phI/II study to evaluate the use of Botox as a treatment for osteoarthristis knee pain
This study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of a single 200U dose administered into the intra-articular space compared with placebo as treatment for osteoarthritis (OA) knee pain.
Timelines, Numbers, Location
The study has just started recruiting and is planned to enroll 120 subjects. Completion is planned for April 2013. The study will be undertaken in Denmark.
Key Endpoints (Baseline and 12 weeks)
Primary Outcome Measures:
  • Change from Baseline in Daily Worst Pain Score
Secondary Outcome Measures:
  • Change from Baseline in Western Ontario McMaster Arthritis Index (WOMAC™) Total Index Score
  • Change from Baseline in WOMAC Pain Score
  • Change from Baseline in WOMAC Physical Function Score
  • Change from Baseline in Patient Global Impression of Change Score
ClinicalTrial Identifier NCT01518257
From http://clinicaltrials.gov, see original source.
